PETITION.TITLE: Allens Creek, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Allens Creek, Australian Capital Territory
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are gravely concerned that a residential suburb shall be built in Allens Creek near Kambah in the Murrumbidgee Gorge Corridor of the Australian Capital Territory.
Your petitioners declare that the Murrumbidgee Gorge Corridor near Canberra in almost unspoilt native forest should be part of the National Estate.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled shall take all possible steps to prevent the building of a residential development in Allens Creek in the Murrumbidgee Gorge Corridor.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telegram Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of New South Wales respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to withdraw public telegram facilities and downgrade telegram standards by:
(1) planning to withdraw the 24 hour telegraph service at the Chief Telegraph Office in each capital city and in Canberra and Darwin
(2) closing country telegraph offices
(3) increasing telegram charges whilst downgrading the service
(4) withdrawing telegram operating facilities from a large number of suburban and country post offices
(5) generating serious delays in telegram delivery by reducing standards of service through centralisation of the network and reduction of operating and delivery staff

will reduce an available means of communications in commercial enterprise, deny the opportunity for people of Australia to make contact with family and friends in times of emergency, and civil or natural disasters, particularly for the 30% of Australians who are not telephone subscribers.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will take measures to ensure the maintenance of an efficient, effective public telegram service to meet the needs of the Australian people socially, publicly, commercially and in times of emergencies and civil or natural disasters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Georges (from 22 citizens) and Scott (from 12 citizens).

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CHANEY; GEORGES; KILGARIFF; ARCHER; LEWIS; MACKLIN; MARTIN; RAE; ROBERTSON; WITHERS
PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that 'The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State'. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women, believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) 'The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels' as described in Part 3, Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3, Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from 180 citizens), Georges (from 92 citizens), Kilgariff ( on behalf of Senator Archer) (from 15 citizens), Lewis (from 51 citizens), Macklin (from 99 citizens), Martin (from 140 citizens), Peter Rae (from 30 citizens), Robertson (from 84 citizens) and Withers (from 85 citizens).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to some statements made by the Prime Minister in another place last Thursday, 12 May, in answer to a question from Dr Theophanous and as recorded on page 506 of Thursday's Hansard. The Prime Minister said, amongst a number of things, that Mr Combe had been given an ' historically unprecedented opportunity of knowing why the Government had acted as it did'. The Prime Minister also said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . this Government moved to do everything immediately within its power to see that Mr Combe had every opportunity to look at the facts as we, the Government, knew those facts.

I ask: Is the Attorney-General aware of a statement by Mr Combe on the Sunday program last Sunday in which Mr Combe referred to and described the way in which he was given knowledge of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation tapes? He described that opportunity as follows:
. . . to sit pat, on my own, without my solicitor, while the Director-General of ASIO read excerpts to me.
As the Attorney-General participated in these talks with Mr Combe, will he tell us whether it is the Prime Minister or Mr Combe who is telling the truth about the discussions held last Wednesday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of a number of statements that have been made by Mr Combe since last week, including the one to which the honourable senator refers. I simply make the point that no request was made to me-certainly no request that I can recall-by Mr Combe that his solicitor be present during the morning session when the extracts from the transcripts in question and other material were put to him. Certainly, when his solicitor was present in the afternoon I made it clear that if there was any desire on the part of either Mr Combe or his solicitor to go back over any matter of fact that might be relevant in determining the content of the statement-to which statement Mr Combe agreed line by line-there would be no question of that access being denied.

ANSWER.PARA: I make the further point that undoubtedly there are likely to be a number of matters of disputed fact not only as to the circumstances of the original Government decision, but also as to the subsequent handling of the case by the Government, which honourable senators opposite may wish to pursue and, indeed, other people in the community may wish to pursue. There is now an opportunity for them to do so in the context of the judicial inquiry, the terms of which are being announced by the Prime Minister early this afternoon.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question because Senator Evans has avoided answering the major point of the question, namely, the accuracy of the Prime Minister's statement:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . Mr Combe had every opportunity to look at the facts as we, the Government, knew those facts.
Mr Combe makes it perfectly clear that only excerpts of the full story available to the Government were read to him. I want to know who is telling the truth-the Prime Minister or Mr Combe?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister is undoubtedly telling the truth in his account of the events. Mr Combe was given an unprecedented opportunity. He did not seek to take that opportunity any further than in the circumstances as I have described them. Should he wish to do so, in the context of the inquiry, no doubt he will take that opportunity. Equally, that opportunity is available to anyone else, including the honourable senator, who may wish to put evidence or argument to the inquiry.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator MacGIBBON

TALK.START.PARA: —In light of widespread concern about confusion in Government decision-making, I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether he misled the Senate last Thursday in regard to the Government's moves to establish a royal commission into the Combe-Ivanov affair. I ask him whether he recalls stating, in answer to a question by Senator Chaney directed specifically at, and emphasising the point of, whether or not the Government would hold a judicial inquiry into Mr Combe's role:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Prime Minister set in train over a week ago the mechanisms for establishing a judicial inquiry into this matter.

As it now appears from subsequent statements of the Prime Minister and Senator Gareth Evans that the decision to include Mr Combe was taken only last Thursday morning, will the Leader explain exactly when the decision to inquire into the Combe affair was made and when he was first aware of that decision?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The decision to include Mr Combe and associated matters in the terms of the royal commission was made, as I understand it, last Thursday. I say 'as I understand it, last Thursday' because the point of Senator MacGibbon's question, as I understand it, is whether, in answering a question that day, I said that the question of setting a royal commission in train had been undertaken a week before. That is perfectly true. If one reads the question the Opposition asked me last week in relation to this matter one sees that the question asked today is a misleading question in this sense: The question that Senator Chaney asked me last week-I do not have it in front of me-was whether the Government would set up a judicial inquiry into this whole matter. The ' whole matter' which I took him to refer to was the question of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. Of course, the answer which I gave was yes, because that was Australian Labor Party election policy, it was a matter which I knew was already in train in terms of the Prime Minister consulting with a potential royal commissioner about his availability to conduct such a commission , and the 'whole matter' to which I took Senator Chaney's question to refer was the question of an investigation into ASIO. The decision about Mr Combe's involvement was, as I say, I believe made on the Thursday after the matter had been raised in the Parliament on the Tuesday and Wednesday by members of the National Party.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Will the Leader of the Government in the Senate agree that his unfortunate use of the word 'bizarre' last week would be the best description possible of this decision -making process on the run and his lack of knowledge of the subject?
—The use of the word 'bizarre' was made in the context of the Opposition's question, which was: Would the Government set up a royal commission to clear Mr Combe's name in this whole matter?
—To allow Mr Combe.
—That was the question. Would the Government set up a royal commission to clear Mr Combe's name?
—To allow Mr Combe to clear his name.
—All right; to allow Mr Combe to clear his name. The answer to that question was no, because if we embarked upon a course of setting up royal commissions every time somebody had to clear his name--

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a minute. Having already foreshadowed a decision to set up a royal commission in relation to ASIO and, at the time the question was asked, consultations taking place with Mr Combe, as they were, in relation to his position-consultations which produced an agreed statement on the Wednesday evening-it was an extraordinary request that a royal commission be set up into those matters.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy a question concerning an Australian Associated Press report in the weekend Press that the Director- General of the International Atomic Energy Agency, Dr Hans Blix, told Mr Hayden:

QUESTION.PARA: Supplier countries with less concern about safeguard arrangements would step in to fill the gap if Australia ceased exporting uranium.

Does the Minister recall that on 22 April this year, in reply to a question from Senator Macklin, he stated that he fully endorsed that item in the Australian Labor Party platform which states quite explicity that as long as France continues to test atomic weapons, Australian uranium, regardless of all other constraints which may be in that platform, will not be supplied to France? Is the report true in saying that the Government has not suspended sales of uranium to France, such as the sales by Queensland Mines Ltd to Electricite de France? If this is true, will the Minister explain the apparent contradication that the Government would not be allowing sales of uranium to France to continue ? Finally, will the Minister assure the Senate that so-called threats of the type used by Dr Blix will not lead the Government to adopt the morality of a heroin pusher and continue to export uranium just because some other country might step in to fill the gap?

Sentor WALSH-I have not seen the AAP report to which Senator Chipp referred, but I have seen similar reports in a number of other papers in the last few days. As I recall, Senator Chipp quoted correctly what I said in the Senate on 22 April when, in answer to a question from Senator Macklin, I referred him, although I did not have a copy with me-and I still do not-to the relevant item in the Australian Labor Party Platform. The second part of Senator Chipp's question asked whether the Government had suspended sales of uranium to France. In March Mr Bowen terminated the negotiating rights-that is not the precise term but that is the meaning-or licences of all uranium producers. I am not sure whether he has restored the negotiating rights to Queensland Mines Ltd. I will have to seek further information from Mr Bowen on that.

Perhaps I should add, because there has been some confusion about this, that the administrative arrangements provide that the question of export licences for uranium or anything falls within the Department of Trade, and is therefore Mr Bowen's area of responsibility and not mine. In regard to the final part of the question concerning the statements that have been coming out of Europe, Mr Hayden announced some time ago that a review of safeguard arrangements was under way. I would expect the question of sales to France to be one of those matters considered, in conjunction, of course, with the Party's platform requirements in this area, by Mr Hayden and other relevant Ministers when finalising that review of safeguard arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is not my task to put the Minister in difficulty, but I just want a categoric answer, if it is possible, stemming from his last sentence. Can I take it from that sentence that at this point the Government does not have a final policy position on stopping all sales of uranium to France while testing is taking place?
—I have said that Mr Bowen is the Minister who actually will be administering this decision.
—But you are a member of Cabinet.

—Yes, I am a member of Cabinet. I am not trying to evade the question, but the matter, in conjunction with other similar matters in relation to uranium mining, is currently under review. I am sorry that I cannot give the honourable senator a categoric statement of government policy at this stage; the matter is still under review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer . In view of last month's reported unemployment figures which show the number out of work in Australia for April as being 707,300, or 10.2 per cent of the work force, but on a seasonally adjusted basis show 715,000 out of work, or 10.3 per cent of the work force, I ask: Firstly, what is the Government's interpretation of the significance of the seasonally adjusted figures? Secondly, will the Government consider bringing back monthly Commonwealth Employment Service reports of registered unemployed? Thirdly, does the Minister share the view of the former Liberal Premier of Western Australia and now Leader of the Opposition, Mr Ray O'Connor, as reported in the West Australian last Friday? He is reported as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: There was a significant decline in employment probably because the Labor Government abandoned the Liberal Government's initiatives.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the first part of Senator Cook's question, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, from my recollection, has made public statements of an intention to restore-I am not sure whether on a monthly basis or at some longer interval than that; I am reminded that it was on a three-monthly basis-the regional unemployment Commonwealth Employment Service statistics, the publication of which the previous Government suspended in accordance with its policy of providing the mushroom treatment for the electorate. ANSWER.PARA: I turn to the statement by Mr O'Connor. Mr O'Connor is a discredited former Premier whose life expectancy as Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia I would not assess as being very long. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, follows the question asked by Senator MacGibbon as to whether an answer given by Senator Button last week misled the Senate. I remind the Leader of the Government that, in my question last Thursday, after referring to the question asked by Senator MacGibbon, I asked:

QUESTION.PARA: In view of the serious questions left unanswered by Mr Hawkes' statement and the devastating effect it has had on Mr Combe, will the Government establish a judicial inquiry in regard to the whole affair and the manner in which the Prime Minister has handled it?
Senator Button's response is recorded in Hansard as follows:
The answer to the Leader of the Opposition's question is yes. The Prime Minister set in train over a week ago the mechanisms for establishing a judicial inquiry into this matter.

I ask: Does the Minister not agree that the question I asked him clearly raises the issue of a royal commission into the whole affair, including the implication of Mr Combe, and that the answer given by the Leader of the Government clearly suggests that a judicial inquiry of that scope was set in train more than a week before the question was asked? Is it not a fact that a judicial inquiry of that scope was not decided upon until that morning and that in fact the answer is, therefore, misleading?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. On Wednesday last, I was asked a question by Senator MacGibbon in relation to a royal commission to enable, as he put it, Mr Combe to clear his name. In my view, on the Wednesday no circumstances existed or were publicly known-other than the fact that Mr Combe alleged he had been defamed in a Sydney newspaper in respect of which he had taken action-which would entitle Mr Combe or any other citizen in those circumstances to warrant the establishment of a royal commission for those purposes as described in Senator MacGibbon's question. On the Thursday, Senator Chaney asked me a question which related in part to Senator MacGibbon's question and included the expression:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . will the Government establish a judicial inquiry in regard to the whole affair?

I took the expression 'the whole affair' to mean the allegations which had been published in the National Times, the expulsion of Ivanov, the public discussion which had taken place about the role of ASIO and, as at Thursday, in part of course, the allegations which were floating around about Mr Combe as a result of the statement made on the Wednesday night.

In those circumstances I say that the answer that I gave to the Senate on the Thursday was an accurate answer. As I have said earlier today, the decision to include Mr Combe was made on the Thursday morning, as I understand it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Referring to the answer just given, is it not a fact that the royal commission or the judicial inquiry which was envisaged to Thursday morning was an inquiry into ASIO and not into the Ivanov involvement or into the Combe involvement?

—When I was asked that question I took it to be an inquiry into this whole affair, which embraced ASIO, Ivanov and all those matters which were currently public knowledge as at the time the question was asked.
—Mr President--
—I call Senator Tate.
—I wish to put exactly the same question.
—With great respect, the honourable senator cannot do that. He has had a question and a supplementary question. The rights of other honourable senators have to be protected.
—I cannot put the question when it is not answered.
—I call Senator Tate.

—Has the Attorney-General seen a letter published in various newspapers today which criticises the Governor-General as identifying himself with a controversial political point of view in launching the book Australia's Constitution-Time for Change? Is the Attorney-General aware of that book? Will he comment on the allegations made by these two puny professors of politics against the Governor-General?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the book in question since I was its joint author along with Haddon Storey, a former Liberal Attorney-General of Victoria under the Hamer and Thompson governments. The third joint author was John McMillan. The book is not a partisan work in any way, shape or form, as might be appreciated from its authorship, but is an attempt at an even-handed discussion of some of Australia's, indeed all of Australia's, obvious constitutional problems, or what are alleged or argued by different people around the country from different points of view to be constitutional problems.

ANSWER.PARA: The object of the book which forms part of a project-as this chamber would no doubt be well aware, set in train and funded by the New South Wales Law Foundation, itself a non-party organisation-was, in the language of its preface, 'to canvas in as dispassionate and non-partisan manner as is humanly possible the full range of problems, or potential problems, to which the present constitution gives rise, to explore the possible solutions and to suggest some options for the machinery by which they might be solved'.

I have indeed seen the criticism which has been directed to the Governor- General, Sir Ninian Stephen, in launching that book in the company of many distinguished judges, including Sir Laurence Street, and a whole range of members of the legal and political establishment a few weeks ago, just before the Australian Constitutional Convention held in Adelaide. I believe that the concept of criticism of the very idea of constitutional review which is inherent in the criticism of these two gentlemen-Professors Kemp and Davis-is quite misplaced.

Divisiveness on this issue springs from the way in which such tasks are sometimes approached. I think it demonstrates a regrettable narrow-mindedness that the whole issue should be viewed in this way by Professor Kemp. I remind the Senate-not that it will need much reminding-that Professor Kemp was formerly on the personal staff of the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, in a most senior private position and was the primary author, as I understand it, of the Edmund Barton Lecture in March 1982 when Mr Fraser, the then Prime Minister, said:

There is no prospect of a new constitution by 1988 as some are suggesting. Nor is a totally new Constitution in any way required. The effort to achieve such an objective is indeed one of the most divisive proposals that can be contemplated in Australia.
Mr Fraser may be politically dead, but it is apparent that his spirit lingers on through the voice of people like Professor Kemp.

I finally say simply that the subject of constitutional review is one to which Governors-General in the past have quite properly addressed themselves in the context of lending their name and their office to the encouragement of rational debate on this issue although not, of course, to any particular proposed solution. I remind the Senate of the role played by Sir Zelman Cowen in this respect in his opening speech to the Perth Constitutional Convention in 1978 and , indeed, of the speech of Sir Ninian Stephen to the opening session of the Constitutional Convention in Adelaide a few weeks ago in which he made exactly the same points as he made at the launching of the book. It seems to me that opponents of a balanced and serious discussion of constitutional reform of the kind that is endeavoured to be contained in this book are simply demonstrating not only their prejudices but also their fears at what such a balanced and rational discussion might disclose about the present state of constitutional affairs in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is Mr W. P. Butler a member of the Government's Ministerial Staff Advisory Panel? Does he participate in decisions to select staff for employment in ministerial offices? Does he sign letters to successful applicants? Is this the same Bill Butler who is an associate in a lobbying business with Mr Richard Farmer, at one time a potential partner of Mr David Combe? Does Senator Button see any potential conflict of interest in a situation in which lobbyist is involved in placing staff in ministerial offices?
—The answer to the first part of the question is yes. I believe it to be same Bill Butler, although I do not know him. The answer to the last part of the question is no.

—Can the Minister representing the Special Minister of State indicate whether the Australian Federal Police action in seizing thousands of video recordings from Electronic Sales and Rentals in Sydney last month was undertaken at the request of a former Commonwealth Police officer who is now working for the Australasian Film Security Office, which acts on behalf of the American Motion Picture Association Inc.

—The actions of the Australian Federal Police in this matter do not appear to constitute one of the finest hours of that force. I hasten to add that it is unfortunate that it appears that the search warrant, in this instance, was in fact executed by the officers in question or without recourse to what is normally the case, and that is advice from the Attorney-General's Department. However, I am advised that the reason the action was taken to seize the tapes was thoroughly well motivated-namely, belief in possible breaches of the Commonwealth Copyright Act. I understand that the AFP received information alleging breaches of that Act through the Australasian Film Security Office, as was mentioned by the honourable senator in his question. I am informed that two members of that office are former members of the Commonwealth Police. Beyond that it would not appear proper to comment because the matter is still currently before the High Court of Australia. I believe it would be inappropriate to make further comment about the substantive merits of the case or the issues lying behind it beyond what I have already said.

—Does the Attorney-General recall attempting last week to blame the Opposition for making Mr Combe's name public in connection with the Ivanov case? How does he square this charge with his comment on the Sunday television program that information involving David Combe had dribbled out 'not least through David's own conversations around town, I suspect' and Mr Combe's statement on the same program 'that the dogs were barking my name in the halls of Parliament House early last week'? In view of the admitted gross security indiscretion by the Special Minister of State, Mr Mick Young, over the Ivanov affair, does the Government accept that Mr Young did not leak Mr Combe's Ivanov connection, despite claims to the contrary? Will Mr Young remain a member of the Cabinet committee dealing with national security? Finally, will the Attorney- General now accept that the Government's bizarre handling of the Ivanov case was the reason for Mr Combe being publicly identified and that, in the words of one senior Press gallery journalist, Mr Hawke has nobody to blame but his own Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dogs may have been barking around the halls of Canberra- indeed, the cats may have been miaowing-but no one mentioned Mr Combe's name in any public context, let alone under the cover of privilege, until that honour was performed by Mr Sinclair as part of a deliberately orchestrated Question Time in the other place as, indeed, there was a similar attempt at an orchestrated Question Time in this place. It was quite contemptible in all circumstances of the case, including the circumstance of a very elaborate briefing of the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, who knew well the nature and extent of Mr Combe's involvement in the circumstances leading up to the expulsion of Mr Ivanov. The Government has nothing whatsoever to apologise for in identifying the Opposition as the key agent in bringing this matter to the public's attention.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that the air has been thoroughly cleared on the question in relation to the Special Minister of State by the public statements that have been made by Mr Young describing what he readily conceded to be an indiscretion in his one sentence comment about the anticipated action of the Government later in that day, which statement was, of course, also confirmed by the statement of Mr Cameron made last week. Again this desperate attempt by the political down and outs opposite to rummage around the rubbish bins to produce a matter of this kind does no credit to their performance as an Opposition. I repeat that the Government has nothing to apologise for in respect of any aspect of its handling of this case at any time. To the extent that any honourable senator opposite or anyone in the community believe to the contrary, the avenue is now open for them to lay such charges before the inquiry that has been established for this purpose, amongst others.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Resources and Energy been drawn to the editorial in last Saturday's Australian newspaper which, amongst other things, expressed grave doubts about the wisdom of a resource rent tax. It claimed:

QUESTION.PARA: The arguments against a Federal Government resource rent tax . . . are compelling. The tax would be inequitable and arbitrary in its nature and in its impact.
Is there any substance in any of these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see that editorial. At least two editorials of similar tone have appeared in the Australian newspaper recently. I suspect that they have a common author, although I do not know who that author is. However, it is quite clear from reading those editorials that the right wing political prejudices of that author eclipse whatever knowledge of the facts he may have or comprehension of the issues involved. The common denominator of both of those editorials has been ignorance of the facts and economic illiteracy. The author can call that tax arbitrary. I suppose people can call any tax arbitrary but I would have thought that any reasonable person would conclude that a tax related to profit was less arbitary than a tax related to production, a tax which must be paid by an enterprise whether or not it is operating profitably. It is a fixed tax on output and it is such fixed taxes on output which the Government proposes to replace by a resources rent tax.

ANSWER.PARA: The writer of that editorial-as I said before, whatever capacity he has to understand the issues is eclipsed by his right wing political prejudices- suggested that the only reason the Government was not imposing a resource rent tax on wheat or wool is that it would incur the wrath of most Australians. There is, of course, no tax on wheat and wool production and therefore no tax on marginal production. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. I refer to an article in the Adelaide News of 9 May which stated that confusion over sales tax could be costing the public millions of dollars a year because some retailers were setting profit margins on top of sales tax levied at the wholesale level. I ask: Will the Government investigate whether this practice is widespread? If it is the case, what action can be taken to prevent retail prices to consumers being inflated by this device?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Maguire, if I remember correctly, raised this issue at an Estimates Committee meeting last week. The Income Tax Assessment Act requires sales tax to be levied on manufacturers or wholesalers at the time an article is sold to retailers and at the appropriate rate levied on the wholesale price. I am advised that the administration beyond that is not a matter for the Australian Taxation Office and that so far as the Taxation Act is concerned retailers can charge whatever they like. If they like to add on a notional sales tax to the retail price instead of the wholesale, that is not an offence under the Taxation Act although, if retailers misrepresent the magnitude of the sales tax being imposed in a way, for example, that adds on sales tax to the total price, including the retailer's mark-up, and does that on a docket or an invoice , I am advised that that could be a matter for prosecution under the Trade Practices Act, but it does not entail a breach of the Taxation Act.

ANSWER.PARA: The practice, if it does exist, of adding sales tax on to retailers' margins as well as the wholesale price upon which it is properly levied is dishonest and anti-social. I will see that this request is passed on to the appropriate Minister to see what evidence can be gathered and whether, in the event of some retailers misrepresenting the magnitude of sales tax, appropriate action can be taken against them.

—I ask the Attorney-General, representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, whether he is aware that statements are being made in north Queensland that the Australian Government is planning to change the terms of the Australia- Papua New Guinea Border Agreement. Is the Government planning any changes and, if not, when will the treaty be ratified?

—I have heard some such suggestions, which have been conveyed to me largely through the medium of Senator Jones in conversation. The situation is this: The Torres Strait treaty beween Papua New Guinea and Australia was signed by the Prime Ministers and Foreign Ministers of both countries in December 1978. It has had the full support of successive governments in both countries since its signature as an imaginative solution to a very complex border problem. I have heard no serious suggestion at all that it should be changed in any way; certainly, the present Government is not contemplating any such change. The agreement will be ratified when the necessary legislation has been passed in both Papua New Guinea and Australia to give effect to its provisions. The drafting of this legislation, which is by no means a simple matter, has been proceeding in both countries and I am informed it has reached an advanced stage in both. I expect on present information that it will be possible for the enabling legislation to be introduced into this Parliament during the Budget sittings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

—Yes, the Government has made a decision about Orana which, as Senator Elstob said, is a very large organisation which looks after intellectually handicapped people in South Australia. DEBATE.TITLE: RECOGNITION OF OVERSEAS PROFESSIONAL QUALIFICATIONS IN AUSTRALIA

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The two-volume report of the committee of inquiry is an excellent document. It is one of those reports which show that the committee's inquiry has been comprehensive, thorough and detailed and that its recommendations probably need very little by way of additional contributions from any interdepartmental committee or the Government before they can be accepted in toto. I think the summary of the various recommendations in volume 1 of the report illustrates the comprehensiveness with which the Committee of Inquiry undertook its task.

I wish to draw attention only to one recommendation which I believe is crucial. It is Recommendation 23 on page 139 of volume 1 and it deals with the necessity for a permanent body. When they read these reports, honourable senators may be interested to know that the assessment of overseas qualifications will be seen as a fairly complex matter requiring not only a great deal of delicacy of judgment but also a fairly detailed working understanding of tertiary institutions and sub-tertiary institutions in countries other than Australia. There are a variety of degrees, diplomas, certificates, courses and standings of various institutions in other parts of the world. I take the example of a person from another country who comes to Australia, presents his or her qualifications to the appropriate body and requests employment of the same standing in Australia as enjoyed in his or her home country. Up to the present, such a request was presented to a board which was a temporary part of the process of sifting through these qualifications. In that respect, we can entertain grave doubts as to the capacity of that temporary body to make a thorough and detailed investigation and a comprehensive and justifiable judgment on a request put to it by such a migrant. Obviously prior to and post World War II, a vast amount of injustice was done in relation to migrants and their qualifications. It was not until the establishment of the committee which is the subject of the inquiry that we had any rationalisation in this area or any opportunity of operating in a fair and reasonable way. I think the Committee has now shown the quality of its work. That quality can only be enhanced by making it a permanent body.

I am unsure, on reading the report, as to the nature of the body that is requested. But I believe that in essence we should not be looking at a body in which the final determiner is permanent. It could very well be a body which is made up from time to time of suitably qualified people. However, one part that ought to be permanent is a small research secretariat which will be able to make recommendations on the basis of understanding and knowledge of overseas qualifications and educational structures. I hope that all the recommendations, in particular Recommendation 23, which are so sensible and reasonable, may come to fruition and that the council proposed in Recommendation 28, chapter 10, may soon be established by the Government so that this task can be put on a permanent footing and this work, which is so necessary for migrants coming to this country, can be maintained at the high level at which it is currently taking place.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

For example, there is concern on the part of schools as to how moneys raised within the school communities should be regarded and dealt with and the accounting requirements in relation to these moneys. Concern has also been expressed as to whether the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority should go on to an accrual system of accounting or whether it could carry on with the system which it had been using for some time. The matter has been one of considerable difficulty.

Although the report is some time out of date, I have moved that the Senate take note of it to try to make it clear that the Authority, throughout this time has been active and diligent in pursuit of this question; that it has been seeking an answer but the question has been bogged down both within the advisings department-within the Attorney-General's Department-and within the Department of Finance, that it has been awaiting advice from the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations; and that it has been trying to deal with different Ministers to try to get an amendment to its Ordinance. It is desirable that the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority get some clarity and certainty on this matter, that it is able to bring its financial statements for the next year up to date and that it has solved for it some of the quite difficult matters of knowing how moneys received by its schools as well as moneys received by the Authority through the Appropriation Bills should be regarded.

As a person who comes from a State, Western Australia, which has a large number of Aborigines and having been over most of the schools that operate in the Aboriginal communities, my concern was that the Curriculum Development Centre was, at long last, providing some material which was of great benefit not only to the students, but also to the people who went to teach at the community schools.

I am sure that all honourable senators remember the Noonkanbah situation which developed under the former Western Australian Liberal Government. It had the effect of sheltering the Noonkanbah community to the extent that it was almost impossible for teachers to concentrate the children's attention on education. It also created other social problems in that community which meant that teaching became a very difficult area. Shortly after that time the CDC was savagely hacked by the former Government, which meant that valuable information, advice and literature that should have been made available to the Noonkanbah community were no longer available. SPEECH.PARA: As a professor of Australian literature she decided that she would talk about educational standards and she obviously displayed that she knows nothing at all about them. She impugned teachers in Australian schools in a way which I think cannot be put up with. The evidence of standards in schools-this evidence has been available for quite some time-is not as Professor Kramer said or as editorialists continually write. These standards have not gone down. They have been maintained. They may not have increased as rapidly as we would like but that is a totally different matter.

She made a statement about the glorious past and our parents being better educated than we were. It displays a complete ignorance of educational history in this country to continue to perpetrate and peddle that conception. The facts are that large numbers of those people now show up as problems only because they are in schools. In the times of our parents they were jettisoned out of school; they were not in school to be a problem. If someone-particularly a person of the standing of Professor Leonie Kramer-would kindly look at the number of people who were in our schools in the times that she is referring to, it would be noted that we have made an enormous jump in the past 15 or 20 years in terms of being able to maintain many more children in schools and at least giving them some basis and some hope of being able to make their way in our society.

There was no golden age of education in Australia, as is constantly referred to , when everybody could read and write. True, all of those who passed the last year in primary school could read and write because the ones who could not worked on the farm, helped at the shop or were somewhere else. They were out of school by the time they reached grade 3 or grade 4. That is simply a matter of history. I wish that when people make comments on education they would get their facts right and not engage in peddling this type of idiotic rumour and idiotic suggestion about falling standards and thereby constantly undermine the morale of teachers in our schools. They have a difficult enough job as it is. The changes in our social structure and in society are bearing down constantly on the schools. For people who are in positions of authority and who ought to know better to make such silly statements does not help anybody.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Mr President, I am pleased to be able to introduce this Bill into the Senate. The Report of the Committee of Review of the ABC (known as the Dix Report), which was tabled in Parliament on 29 May 1981, has generated a geat deal of enthusiasm for the modernisation of the ABC. In its 273 recommendations the Dix Committee examined all facets of the ABC's structure and operations and identified many areas requiring change. Many recommendations relate to programming and the internal administration of the ABC and will require urgent attention by the Board of the new Corporation.

Accordingly, one of the early priorities of this government is to reintroduce legislation to establish the Australian Broadcasting Corporation so that the important work of reconstruction and modernisation of Australia's national broadcaster can proceed.

It is now two years since the Dix Committee reported to government. Unless immediate action is taken to proceed with the restructuring of the ABC and the implementation of the Dix Report, the enthusiasm for change generated by that Report will inevitably wane. Until new ABC legislation is passed there can be no effective implementation of the Dix Committee's recommendations.

Mr President, this Government is committed to maintaining a strong and independent ABC, able to meet the broadcasting needs of the Australian people. This Government believes that as Australia's only national broadcaster the ABC has served and must be able to continue to serve in the fore-front of Australian broadcasting.

This Bill and its companion Bill, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation ( Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1983, establish the legislative basis for the new Corporation. They are largely based on the Bills introduced last year by the former Government. However, a number of changes have been made to reflect Government policy and I shall draw attention to these as I outline the major features of the legislation.

The provisions in the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 covering the ABC were drafted many years ago and are now largely outmoded. This Bill modernises the legislative base for the ABC. An important innovation is to establish the ABC under its own Act of Parliament. This will help make the ABC's legislation more accessible to the public at large.

Mr President, for years the ABC has suffered from the lack of an adequate definition of the role it should play in the Australian broadcasting system. Over the years, this has led to uncertainty in the organisation about which direction it could take-whether to concentrate on wider appeal programming or whether to provide the sort of specialist programming not available on commercial stations. It is appropriate that Parliament should take this opportunity to provide that direction.

This Bill gives the ABC a Charter which clearly sets out its functions and obligations. The Charter, included in Clause 6 of the Bill, requires the Corporation to provide innovative and comprehensive radio and television services of a high standard-to provide programs that contribute to a sense of national identity and which inform, entertain and reflect the cultural diversity of the Australian community. The Charter makes it clear that there will need to be a balance between programs of wide appeal and more specialised programs. It also acknowledges the ABC's role as an international broadcaster and as provider of educational programs and reaffirms the ABC's role in encouraging and promoting the musical, dramatic and other performing arts in Australia.

The Dix Committee criticised the ABC for failing to take account of changes in the composition of the Australian community. The Charter has been expanded to include a provision requiring the Corporation to recognise the multicultural character of today's Australian society.
In addition to spelling out the functions of the Corporation, the Bill places certain statutory responsibilities on the Board and prescribes the role of the Corporation's Managing Director.
The responsibilities of the Board will include:
(1) ensuring that the Corporation's functions are performed efficiently and to the maximum benefit of the Australian people;
(2) maintaining the independence and integrity of the Corporation;
(3) ensuring that the gathering and presentation of news and information is accurate and impartial according to the recognised standards of objective journalism; and
(4) ensuring the ABC's compliance with the Act and other relevant legislation.

The Managing Director will be responsible for managing the affairs of the Corporation and will exercise significant administrative powers in his own right . In exercising those powers, the Managing Director will be required, by Clause 10, to act in accordance with any policies determined, or any directions given, by the Board.

Clause 12 of the Bill provides that the new Board will consist of the Managing Director and from 6 to 8 non-executive Directors. The Managing Director will be appointed by the Board on a full-time basis for a period of 5 years, and will be eligible for reappointment for a period not exceeding 5 years. He will be paid such remuneration as is determined by the Remuneration Tribunal.

Non-executive Directors, including a Chairman and a Deputy Chairman, will be appointed on a part-time basis by the Governor-General for terms of up to 5 years. Non-executive Directors must have experience in either radio, television, communications, management, a financial or technical field, or must possess cultural or other interests relevant to the operation of a public organisation providing radio and television services. The Government has decided that one of these Directors should be a staff-elected Director. The Government will be considering how consultations can be held with other political parties regarding nominations to the new Board.

To assist in programming matters, clause 11 of the Bill makes provision for an Australian Broadcasting Corporation Advisory Council. The Bill also allows the Board to establish Advisory Councils in relation to any State, Territory or region of Australia. These Advisory Councils will consist of such persons as the Board from time to time appoints. The Board may also appoint advisory committees to furnish advice on matters relating to the Corporation's functions.

Under clause 25 the Corporation will be given broad powers which are consistent with the powers provided to other comparable statutory bodies. It will be able to enter into contracts, acquire and dispose of real and personal property, erect buildings and structures, appoint agents and attorneys, act as an agent, and engage persons to perform services for the Corporation. It will be able to accept gifts, devises and bequests made to the Corporation. However, it will not have power to borrow money, and it will not be permitted to broadcast or televise advertisements, or to engage in corporate underwriting.

The Bill closes a major loop-hole in the 1982 legislation in relation to corporate underwriting. Sub-clause 25 (3) will now expressly prohibit the Corporation from accepting any payment or other consideration for the broadcasting or televising of any announcement, program or other matter. The only exceptions to this will be in relation to payments received from Commonwealth, State or Territory Governments or authorities, or from bona fide producers or publishers who have entered into specified co-operative arrangements with the ABC.

The 1982 legislation would have virtually prevented the Corporation from accepting services, facilities, gifts, devises or bequests, except in relation to its concert or merchandising activities, whether or not there was any risk to the independence or integrity of the Corporation. This provision has been modified to allow the Corporation to accept such assistance where there is no such risk.

The Government is committed to maintaining the ABC's independent news service. The provisions of Section 66 of the Broadcasting and Television Act covering the ABC's radio news service have been incorporated in clause 27 of the Bill but have been extended to cover television. This will, for the first time, provide statutory recognition of an independent ABC news service for television. In addition the provision has been amended to make it clear that allowing the Corporation to procure news and information from international or domestic news agencies does not affect the statutory obligation placed on the Managing Director to employ an adequate number of persons for the collection of ABC news and information. The legislation will thereby ensure that the Corporation does not reduce its own news staff by relying, for example, on news and information procured from a domestic news agency.

Clauses 28 and 29 of the Bill make provision for the ABC's use of orchestras and bands, for ABC concerts and other entertainments and for the ABC's merchandising activities. In line with the proposal in the Dix Report, clause 30 enables the Corporation, if it thinks fit, to submit children's television programs to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal for classification.

In an important change to the 1982 legislation the Government has decided not to proceed with a Commissioner for Complaints. The establishment of such a statutory position outside the ABC with broad powers to investigate a wide range of complaints smacks of political censorship. However, the Government does accept that there should be some mechanism within the ABC to investigate complaints regarding errors of fact or invasion of privacy. The Bill therefore provides for the Corporation to establish Community Affairs Officers to deal with such complaints.

Under clause 82, a National Community Affairs Officer appointed by the Managing Director will co-ordinate the work of Community Affairs Officers in each State, the A.C.T. and the Northern Territory. If a complaint is found to be justified the Managing Director will be notified and will be required to arrange for a prompt apology or retraction to be broadcast. The ABC will also be required to include a summary of the activities of these officers in its Annual Report to the Parliament.

The Bill extensively updates provisions relating to the administration of the ABC. Part V of the Bill deals with staffing matters. A key change to the current provisions in the Broadcasting and Television Act is the severance of all statutory links with the Public Service Board. The ABC will be free to set salary levels and terms and conditions of appointment for all ABC officers and temporary employees. It will, however, continue to participate in existing arrangements administered by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations for the co-ordination of industrial relations policy and practice in Australian Government employment.

Other changes include deletion of the so-called ''No Work as Directed-No Pay'' provisions; deletion of seniority as a criterion for promotion; and provision for appeals against temporary promotions and for more than one Promotions Appeal Board. The Bill also updates provisions relating to disciplinary matters and the redeployment and retirement of ABC staff. In regard to the latter, ABC employees will be able to retire at 55 years and there will be a Tenure Appeal Board to hear appeals relating to redeployment action. The Promotions Appeal Boards, the Tenure Appeal Board and the Disciplinary Appeal Board shall each be composed of a Chairman appointed by the Governor-General, and members nominated by management and by the relevant staff association or union.

Clause 48 of the Bill contains provisions for redeployment of staff on the grounds of excess numbers, physical or mental incapacity, inefficiency or loss of an essential qualification. The Government is to reassess redeployment provisions applying to the public sector generally as part of its review of the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act 1979. The redeployment provisions in the Bill will be reconsidered as soon as that general review has been completed.

I would draw honourable senators' attention to sub-clause 62 (4) of the Bill. This relates to the payment of a pension benefit to any ABC employee who has been retired because he could not be redeployed within the ABC. The provision would enable such a benefit to be paid from the Consolidated Revenue Fund as if it were a benefit payable under the Superannuation Act 1976.

Part VI of the Bill contains the financial provisions applying to the Corporation. These are similar to those applying to the Australian Broadcasting Commission except that the ceiling on contracts for which Ministerial approval is required has been lifted from $250,000 to $500,000. There is also an express provision preventing the ABC from entering into any lease-back agreements unless the approval of the Minister has been obtained.

Part VII of the Bill relates to technical services for the Corporation. This part of the Bill has been re-drafted to remove a number of anomalies in the 1982 legislation and to simplify the provision covering transmission facilities. Under current arrangements in the Broadcasting and Television Act the Minister is generally responsible for the provision and operation of transmission facilities for ABC services. By administrative arrangement Telecom operates and maintains National transmitting stations on the Minister's behalf.

Because many other broadcasters share the facilities of National transmitting stations-including sites, roads, buildings, masts, aerials and so on-it is not appropriate that the stations as such should be controlled by one of their competitors, the ABC. The Bill therefore allows for the continued provision and operation of National transmitting stations by the Minister. However, it also recognises the ABC's need to control its transmitters if it is to be seen to be independent of the Minister. It therefore provides for all ABC transmitters to be transferred to the Corporation and establishes a mechanism allowing the Minister to transfer complete transmitting stations to ownership of the Corporation if he so decides. The result will be that the ABC will have the same control of its transmissions as commercial and public broadcasters sharing National transmitting stations. No transfer of Telecom staff to the ABC will result from these new arrangements.

Part VIII of the Bill incorporates provisions covering the broadcasting or televising of matters in the national interest along the lines of sections 64 and 77 of the Broadcasting and Television Act. It also includes provisions covering annual reporting requirements; the establishment of a Joint Consultative Committee of management, staff and staff associations; and the making of regulations and rules. The Bill empowers the Corporation to make rules , particularly in relation to matters of administration. This will obviate the need to prescribe regulations to cover what are essentially administrative matters. Any rules made by the Corporation will be tabled in the Parliament in accordance with relevant sections of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

The above is only a brief general outline of the major features of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill 1983. For more details I would refer Honourable Senators to the explanatory memorandum circulated with the Bill.

If the ABC is to continue its historic role as the pacesetter in Australian broadcasting, it is essential that its legislation be modernised and improved as proposed in this Bill. Mr President, I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Mr President, this Bill is a companion measure to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill 1983. It provides for certain transitional arrangements associated with the replacement of the Australian Broadcasting Commission by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and makes consequential amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 and a number of other Acts.

This Bill is substantially consistent with the Transitional Bill introduced last year by the former Government. However, the Government has decided not to proceed with provisions covering the transfer of Telecom staff to the ABC. In addition, a saving provision relating to 'No work as directed-No pay' has been deleted as there are now no such provisions in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill.

Part II of the Bill includes all the transitional provisions required because of the establishment of the Corporation. It provides for the cessation of the terms of ABC Commissioners, and includes saving provisions in relation to contracts, awards and other instruments to which the Australian Broadcasting Commission is a party. It makes clear that the alteration in the name and constitution of the Commission does not affect any property, power, rights, liabilities or obligations of the ABC. There are also provisions covering legal or other proceedings involving the ABC, on-going investigations by the Ombudsman and any provisional promotions or disciplinary actions outstanding as of the commencing day.

The Bill makes clear that officers and temporary employees of the Commission continue as officers and temporary employees of the Corporation. All positions established in the service of the Australian Broadcasting Commission will be continued, with the exception of the position of General Manager which will be abolished.

There are also a number of transitional provisions in relation to payment of moneys, estimates, bank accounts and the auditing of the accounts and financial records of the Commission. If the Commission is unable to finalise its Annual Report prior to commencing day, the Bill provides for that report to be finalised by the Corporation.

Part III of the Bill relates to amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act. Most of the amendments omit provisions in that Act relating to the Australian Broadcasting Commission or replace references to the Commission with references to the Corporation. Other provisions preserve the application of certain sections of the Broadcasting and Television Act to the Special Broadcasting Service.

An important change to the Transitional Bill is included in Clause 24, which amends section 31 of the Broadcasting and Television Act relating to the compositiion of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. The Government intends to establish the new Corporation as soon as possible after the legislation has been passed by the Parliament. However, five ABC Commissioners are due to retire during or at the end of June.

Because the provisions in the Broadcasting and Television Act were drafted many years ago, they do not include any provision allowing for the continued operation of the Commission if for some reason, and for some limited period of time, the number of Commissioners falls below the prescribed minimum number. Clause 24, which comes into effect on Royal Assent, inserts such a provision in the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 along the lines of equivalent provisions relating to the composition of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and the Special Broadcasting Service. This will avoid the need to replace ABC Commissioners in the few weeks prior to the establishment of the Corporation.

Parts IV to VII of the Bill make consequential amendments to the Copyright Act 1968, the Freedom of Information Act 1982, the Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act 1946 and the Telecommunications Act 1975 by replacing references to the Commission with references to the Corporation. Mr President, I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for bounty assistance to the manufacturer in Australia of certain refrigerated room air conditioners. Kelvinator Australia Ltd, South Australia is the manufacturer concerned.
The bounty assistance was recommended by the Temporary Assistance Authority ( TAA) in its report No. 56 of 1 October 1982 entitled ''Certain Room Air Conditioning Machines and Parts''.
The bounty recommended by the TAA was accepted by the previous Government and this decision was announced on 27 October 1982. My Government endorses the decision.

The Bill provides for bounty payments on locally produced room air conditioning machines of a portable or fixed window type, designed primarily for use without ducting and having a nominally rated cooling capacity of 5.4 kilowatts or less.

The bounty rates are $60 each for smaller units not exceeding 3.528 kilowatts cooling capacity, and $90 for larger units. The bounty will apply to locally produced room air conditioners sold for use in Australia during the period 27 October 1982 to 30 June 1983, with the total bounty payable being limited to $1. 5m.

In its report of October 1982 the TAA found that urgent assistance was necessary to protect Kelvinator against import competition. The TAA concluded that bounty was the most appropriate means of assisting Kelvinator as most of the imports for the 1982-83 summer selling season were already in the country.

While the bounty scheme provides some incentive for Kelvinator to continue production, it does not insulate the company entirely from normal market forces. The company has advised that without temporary assistance, desirable investment to improve its competitiveness would be unlikely to proceed.

The local industry is still facing difficulties and the Minister for Industry and Commerce sent a further reference to the TAA on 21 April on the question of the continuation of temporary assistance after 30 June 1983. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

This Bill proposes short term bounty assistance to the industry producing certain high alloy steel products.

The goods proposed to be eligible for bounty include a range of high alloy bar products and stainless steel flat products. These steels are used in applications where strength, corrosion resistance, resistance to chemical attack or other special attributes are required.
In addition, these steels are essential for a very wide range of direct defence applications and also underpin general support capabilities for defence activities.

The bounty was recommended by the Temporary Assistance Authority (TAA) in its report No. 57 of 23 December 1982 entitled ''Certain High Alloy Steel Products'' . The previous Government announced on 1 February 1983 that it had accepted the Authority's recommendation and this Government, having reviewed the circumstances, agrees that the assistance should be granted.

The TAA found that imports had secured an increasing proportion of the declining market for these goods, such that the market share held by the local industry had declined from about 80 per cent in 1979-80 to less than 50 per cent at the time of the TAA's inquiry. The particular form of assistance chosen-that is, bounty-was appropriate in the circumstances where it was estimated that imported stocks already entered into the country were estimated to represent at least six months' sales. Thus, tariff associated measures would be ineffective for some considerable time and provide little short term relief.
The Bill provides for the bounty to be paid at the rate of 5 per cent of the price paid or payable for bountiable products produced and sold for use in Australia to a maximum limit of $3m.

The Bill further proposes that the bounty be applicable to manufacturers engaged in the production of eligible goods as at 7 February 1983 and be payable on such goods from 1 January 1983 to 31 December 1983 or the date of implementation of the Government's decision on the Industries Assistance Commission report on the iron and steel industry, whichever occurs first. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was speaking on the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill last Thursday I had the opportunity of making a number of points both in respect of the conduct of this debate and the subject matter of the Bill. I mentioned that the performance of the Opposition in this place and in the House of Representatives indicated a modern form of guerrilla politics. We had almost 50 hours of tiresome, repetitive debate from a rather small group of uncontrollable back benchers in both places. However, I also went on to mention and comment on the subject matter of primary concern to people speaking in respect of this Bill-that is, the South West region of Tasmania-and I also commented on the attributes and values of that area. I then turned to the argument of States rights which has been endlessly pursued by conservative back benchers in this place. I made the point that the powers that this Government-the Australian Labor Government-was seeking to exercise under this Bill were ones that it had not initiated by way of legal process through the High Court of Australia. In fact it was the previous Liberal Government and the relevant and responsible Minister at the time, who is now the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) in the other place, who initiated court proceedings and sought these powers. That was in the Koowarta case, which the Australian Government took to the High Court to seek to have the validity of the legislation upheld. In that case, the High Court did uphold the right and power of this Parliament to act in regard to the implementation of international treaties to the extent that they affect individual Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat that the power being exercised pursuant to this legislation is one that was substantially, though not totally, sought by the conservative forces in this country. They recognised that power as being valid within the armoury of federal powers pertinent to the workings of a federal constitutional system. The point I wish to make is that, if a national government abdicates its responsibility in respect of matters such as the South West of Tasmania, the way is open for conservative State governments, with parochial interests and on extremely parochial issues, to upset our international responsibilities and arrangements. We do not have to look too far to see a situation such as that which arose in regard to the Great Barrier Reef. Generally, Australians understand that the intentions of the conservative National Party Government in Queensland in respect of that area of national heritage are less than holy. We have from the Opposition the rather curious ethic that States should have power but no responsibility; States should have the power to go to hell in their own way and to work in some kind of anarchistic system without responsibility towards national planning and rational and national resource use, without adequate discussion and recognition of important matters whether they be economic, social or related to employment or the environment. We on this side of the House acknowledge that both the national Government and State governments have a responsibility to take these sorts of features into consideration. We do not accept that either tier of government can proceed without recognition of responsibilities in the exercise of its rights.

I turn briefly to the position of the Tasmanian Government on this matter. This Government has had a number of different attitudes expressed to it as being relevant and of concern to the Tasmanian Government. In December 1982, the Premier of Tasmania, Mr Gray, claimed rather loudly that Tasmania needed more power for industry. When he was asked what industry and whether Tasmania should be looking at, say, the steel industry from Wollongong or Alcoa of Australia Ltd from Portland, Mr Gray very quickly changed his line of attack. He then started talking about the need for power for home heating but did not stick to that line of argument for very long. His latest theory is one of State rights. The line of argument that his Government is now pursuing is: Tasmania, as a State, has State 's rights in this matter. Damn the national interests; it is going to exercise its rights. The line from Tasmania has been inconsistent. As I mentioned in my remarks last Thursday, it is one that has effectively let the Tasmanian people down.

When one analyses the economic arguments put forward, one recognises the fallacy behind them. The ethic put forward by the Opposition in this place and elsewhere is that with more capacity for electrical power Tasmania's economy will self-generate, will kick-start and pick up and go. Let us analyse the recent history of this matter to see whether that view is a truism. Between 1947 and 1979, Tasmania's electrical generating capacity increased by over 1,032 per cent. In that same period, employment in the manufacturing industry in Tasmania actually decreased from 20.5 per cent of total employment to 16.1 per cent. There was not a commensurate increase in employment creation. On the misguided theory that has been propounded and put rather forcefully to us, employment in manufacturing industry should very well have increased. In fact, it had gone down. When one makes a closer analysis of the more recent figures, between 1976 and 1979, one notes that the statistics in both areas show that the trends have been downhill all the way. Electrical generative capacity has increased by over 564 per cent while manufacturing employment has decreased by approximately 35 per cent. So there is not an increase in employment commensurate with the increase in electrical generative capacity. That very much gives the lie to the position that has been rather glibly put forward by blinkered interests from Tasmania.

I have spoken on this matter twice. I wish to close my contribution to this debate by reiterating the point I made at the start. We are concerned with an extremely important conservation issue. It is an issue which affects one of the last areas of wilderness in this country, if not the world. It has been accepted by the United Nations Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage as being of importance in terms of its cultural and natural heritage. It has been accepted on all four criteria on which that body makes its assessments-not just one but all four. The United Nations Convention regards that area as being extremely important. It is one that the Australian Government also sees as extremely important. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

I really cannot understand why the Tasmanian Labor senators who represent Tasmania in the Senate, which is a States' House, are so stubborn about the issue.

The Labor Government wants to alter that basis and greatly increase the Commonwealth powers at the expense of the States. ''Convention'' means the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage that has been adopted by the General Conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

TALK.START.PARA: —Down.

I find ridiculous the suggestion that all Tasmanian senators should take the same attitude on the matter just because some proportion-whether it be 50 per cent or 60 per cent or something of that order is arguable-of Tasmanians support the building of the dam.
