One could argue anyway, without going into the details of the economics of the issue, that in fact we will be doing our State a very big favour by ensuring that the dam is not built. Any one who says that we do not know anything about the area is wrong, as I certainly do. I have visited the area. I have visited Tullah, I have visited Strahan and I have visited the blockades; so I have certainly taken note of all sides of the issue.

One matter about the listing of the area by the World Heritage Committee needs emphasising: Some speakers have suggested that the World Heritage Committee listed the area for protection knowing that the dam was going to be built and condoned the building of it. Professor Slatyer, as Australia's representative on that Committee and as the Chairman of the World Heritage Committee, in an article published in various newspapers, including the Age, on 8 January and the Mercury, made it clear that listing by the World Heritage Committee was intended to stop the building of the dam. He has denied that the listing was with the knowledge that the dam would be built no matter what. I will cite some paragraphs of that article by Professor Slatyer. It states:

When the committee considered the nomination it was confronted with a difficult decision. On the one hand the property was clearly quite outstanding and fully warranted its place on the list. On the other hand the committee had been officially advised by Australia--
That is, the former Federal Government-

that the dam was going ahead, so that many of the features on which the nomination was based would be damaged or destroyed. The committee had to decide whether to accept the nomination, defer it or reject it altogether. It knew that , so far, only preliminary work had been undertaken and that serious damage had not yet occurred.

The committee took the view that accepting the nomination was the best course. It was aware that listing would considerably enhance public and government awareness of the value and importance of the area. It was also aware of Australia's impressive record in conservation and heritage matters, nationally and internationally. Acceptance of the nomination was therefore most likely to lead to a reconsideration of the dam project.

It has been suggested that, knowing that dam construction had commenced, the committee's action in listing south-west Tasmania condoned the dam project. This was definitely not the case. In addition to accepting the nomination, the committee adopted the following statement emphasising its serious concern about the dam:
'The committee is seriously concerned at the likely effect of dam construction in the area on those natural and cultural characteristics which make the property of outstanding universal value.
In particular it considers that flooding of parts of the river valleys would destroy a number of cultural and natural features of great significance, as identified in the ICOMOS and IUCN reports.
The committee suggests that the Australian authorities take all possible measures to protect the integrity of the property'.

Although couched in the respectful language characteristic of UN bodies addressing a nation of high international standing, this statement is the strongest made by the committee in the four years that I have been associated with it. It amounts to a plea to the Tasmanian and Australian Governments to find an alternative to dam construction so that this magnificent area can be protected and conserved, not just for the enjoyment of those of us alive now, but so that future generations can also visit and marvel at it.

There are several matters I want to respond to which have been raised by Opposition speakers. They have used terms such as 'the Commonwealth is trespassing on the State's powers'. May I answer that by saying that the Commonwealth is trespassing on the State's powers only if those powers are not allowed to the Commonwealth by the Constitution. That issue will be decided by the High Court of Australia. The matter of whether the Commonwealth has those powers will be dealt with over the road, by the High Court. In view of the fact that it is an international treaty, a multilateral treaty, surely we cannot have a situation where the national Government and its obligations under that treaty can be vetoed by the actions of a State government. That would be a farce.

Senator Martin in her remarks in the second reading debate accused us of not referring the Bill to the Australian Constitutional Convention. Once again, I point out there is no need to refer the matter to the Constitutional Convention because the matter is going to be decided under the Constitution as it now stands. We are not changing the Constitution by stealth, as she accused us. How much more open can we get than to introduce a Bill, allow for debate in this place, have the matter become law and be tested in the High Court? The interpretation of the Constitution is a continually changing matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was alluding to an editorial in the Australian Financial Review. Why don't you address yourself to the subject of that editorial?

—The honourable senator supported the expressions of view in that editorial and used words to the effect that there was need to refer the Bill. We have not done so. I am explaining why we have not done so. As I say, the Constitution is continually changing. It happens by governments legislating and by not having that legislation challenged at all; it happens by governments legislating and winning in the High Court of Australia when that legislation is challenged; and it happens by other decisions of the High Court with or without specific legislation by the Government. Look how the Constitution was effectively changed in respect of trade and commerce by court action in the concrete pipes case a few years ago. That is a matter where the Constitution was changed. Nobody did it by stealth or by the matter not being referred to the Constitutional Convention; it was by the natural evolution of constitutional interpretation which is provided for in the Constitution.

They continually go on about States' rights and the lack of Federal rights in these matters when what we ought to be talking about are responsibilities. Whether the members opposite like it or not, Australia is a party to the World Heritage Convention. It has obligations under that convention and it has particular obligations in areas that have been listed . The area was listed with the support of the previous Tasmanian Government and the previous Federal Government.

Unfortunately damage is being caused in that area at present, much more damage than any one wants to see at the moment, until the High Court hears the matter at the end of the month. I believe that work should stop until the issue is determined in the court. Apart from anything else, it is a vast waste of money or what we hope is a vast waste of money. The Bill provides a means of protection of last resort. As Senator Hill said it would be best if this measure did not have to be used, it would be best to negotiate and come to a consensus. Sometimes, as in this case, when consensus is not possible, legislation is necessary and this measure of last resort has to be used. I point out that the Bill, in taking action to protect areas, is breaking new ground and giving standing to persons and organisations other than the Government. An indication of the Government's magnanimity on this matter is that it accepted very sensible amendments after the Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives- amendments assuring the protection of properties once they were proclaimed.

I could say a lot more on this Bill, but we wish the matter to come to a vote as quickly as possible. I conclude by reiterating that the matter is for the High Court to decide ultimately once this Bill is passed and assented to and the proclamation is made. I cannot understand why Opposition members are so scared about having the matter judged there. They fought it when they were in Government last year and they are continuing that fight. The present Government is going ahead with its election commitment and is doing what it can to ensure that, under the Constitution as it stands, the South West of Tasmania can be preserved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill I wish particularly to discuss some of the major issues which I have discussed publicly over quite some considerable period. The last speaker, Senator Coates, said that the Australian Labor Party Government is acting with magnanimity on this Bill. I do not think this is so much a matter of magnanimity . It is a matter of national duty and responsibility which I believe the Government has and which I believe we on this side of the chamber also have. I hope I discharge that obligation today. I believe that we as Liberals have had for a long time a responsibility to protect the wilderness areas of Tasmania. I believe that the policies we laid down in 1975, which were outlined by Senator Peter Rae in debate on the Australian Democrats' Bill last year, remain obligations which we should be following. I will remind the Senate of what they were.

SPEECH.PARA: We were elected as a government on the basis of an agreement between the Liberals of Tasmania and the Commonwealth, from which agreement the Tasmanian Liberals have resiled by their own wish since that time. In that policy which we had in 1975 and which is completely unrevoked we said it was important that the South West National Park should be extended. We said that there should be an agreement and that early action should be taken to preserve this area. We wanted an enlarged South West National Park and finance for it. Indeed, the Fraser Government did provide some finance for that. We pointed out the need for co- ordination of activities in regard to that area. In particular the policy commitment we had at that time went on to state:

. . . a firm commitment by the Liberal and Country Parties to provide Commonwealth financial assistance to support enlargement of the boundaries. The enlargement of the boundaries will require sacrifice on the part of the Tasmanian State Government and the Tasmanian people in the national interest.
I stress 'in the national interest'. We went on to state:

In effect the Australian people will be asking them to forgo revenue that might otherwise flow from unchecked development of the area in order to preserve for the nation an area considered of immense national significance.

That policy, as Senator Peter Rae pointed out, meant a foregoing of developments in respect of electricity generation, mining and forestry. That policy, unfortunately, has not been carried out. Indeed, we are still obligated to it and should be carrying it out. In the Liberal Party we have a very large number of people who are still committed to the responsibilities in the Tasmanian wilderness area. I will read just two of the paragraphs from a letter circulated to many honourable senators on 18 November 1982 by the then national President of the Young Liberal Movement of Australia, now the Honourable Mark Birrell. Speaking on behalf of the Movement, Mr Birrell said:

We believe there are overwhelming economic, legal, political and, of course, environmental reasons for the Commonwealth Government to stop the construction of the Gordon-below-Franklin dam. The Government should move quickly to protect the Wilderness and should then work with the Tasmanian Government to encourage energy-related development projects in other parts of that State.

Young Liberals have long held the belief that this beautiful area must be saved . At each of the Movement's past two National Conventions, overwhelming support has been given to policy resolutions that condemned the proposed dam and called upon the Commonwealth Government to ensure the area's preservation for all Australians. In addition, the Tasmanian Division of the Young Liberal Movement adopted a resolution opposing the damming of the Gordon or Franklin Rivers in 1979 and has maintained that position ever since.

So many views are held in my party. Many members who were in this Parliament suffered fates in the last election partly because of this issue and I believe I can speak for them today as they are not present. I believe the last poll indicated that we should have a further commitment. A new government was elected in part on the support it gave to the stopping of the construction of the dam and to the preservation of the wilderness area. That is very evident from the figures in Victoria and New South Wales. One can look at the comparative figures for the Democrat vote in the Senate and the way in which people followed the voting the Tasmanian Wilderness Society and other conservation groups recommended to them. Many of my colleagues suffered their fates because of that. I believe that we on this side of the chamber should be honouring their loss today by doing something about the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a look at the figures.

—I say that the figures amply demonstrate that. The Hawke Government was elected on this commitment. It was elected partly because it stood for preserving and stopping the building of this dam. Indeed, it has responsibilities in regard to the wilderness area and the archaeological caves which are threatened with very early disaster. I will quote from one typical example of the representations made to the previous Prime Minister. Experts from the School of Botany in Melbourne stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We stress the interdependent relationship of rivers with the surrounding catchment; actions which alter part alter the whole. The building of a dam necessitates massive destruction from consequential works. By these works and by flooding the Franklin and Gordon valleys rare river-bank and gorge communities will be destroyed, precious temperate rainforest will be wiped out or altered and the endemic, slow-growing and ancient Huon pines which have persisted here for thousands of years will be killed. On scientific grounds we are convinced that these are unacceptable ecological costs. These forests must be preserved for all time in their entirety as part of our natural heritage; they must not be destroyed for short-term and doubtful economic gain.

That statement puts another consideration in this area. Upon this basis there is an obligation on the Government. It is not a matter of magnanimity, but an obligation on government. The Government has introduced regulations. I am sorry the Government did not press for injunctions under those regulations but no doubt it wants to be as safe as possible in its constitutional stand. I can understand that, but I also understand the widespread devastation which has been going on in the Franklin area for some considerable time now and which has speeded up. All this has been brought to a head by the fact that this area has been placed on the World Heritage List at the request of the Commonwealth and the Government of Tasmania. That was not done in secret, nor were the various proclaimed parts which have made up the national parks and the area of that listing. All that was done openly and we had that responsibility. As has been pointed out by Senator Coates, Professor Ralph Slatyer, who is the eminent chairman of the World Heritage Committee and our representative on that Committee, has made it perfectly clear that it was of great concern to the Committee when it found that this was being done. I remind honourable senators of this statement by the Committee:

The Committee is seriously concerned at the likely effect of dam construction in the area on these natural and cultural characteristics which make the property of outstanding universal value in particular, and consider that flooding of parts of the river valleys would destroy a number of cultural and natural features of great significance as identified in the Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources and International Council for Monuments and Sites report.
We recommend to the Australian society to take every possible measure to protect the integrity of the site.
The Committee suggests that the Australian authorities should ask the committee to place the property on the list of world heritage in danger until the question of dams construction is resolved.

As was pointed out by Dr Harry Edwards in a very excellent speech in the House of Representatives, Professor Slatyer also pointed out that in no way did the Committee condone the building of the dam. Indeed, he pointed out that the area could be delisted if, in fact, the building of the dam went ahead. Dr Harry Edwards pointed out-I agree with him-that this would be the first time this has happened and that would be terrible for Australia if it were the first country to have an area delisted. Therefore, there is no doubt about the international obligation which we have accepted and which we must carry out. When people talk about State sovereignty and say how States rights should intervene at this junction and that the States should be allowed to do as they like, I say there is no State sovereignty. There has not been State sovereignty in this sense since 1901. We have ceased to be colonies. There is no federal sovereignty either. The Commonwealth is not free to do as it chooses. We have a sovereign Constitution which divides the various powers amongst governments of Australia. There have been changes in the way those powers have been interpreted over the years and I will come to that in a moment. We on this side of the chamber cannot say that we have not used national responsibilities for the purpose of overriding State rights in some limited sense. Even last Christmas we insisted that the New South Wales and Victorian governments should not charge outpatient fees at hospitals. We interfered with those governments' Budget requirements because we believed that there were national responsibilities with regard to the health scheme. Likewise, we have done this in the conservation areas-in the protection of the Great Barrier Reef and Fraser Island. The previous Governments saw these as responsibilities which override State desires which at times may be expressed.

I turn to this Bill which is designed to strengthen the powers of the Commonwealth and to provide a method whereby South West Tasmania and other areas on the World Heritage List can be protected. The Bill is based on four different heads of power. I remind honourable senators-as the High Court of Australia has reminded people over the years-that they are all independent heads of power. One occasionally reads in debates reported in the House of Representatives Hansard that some people think that these heads of power are subsidiary to some other power, but they are not. If this Bill is upheld on any one of those grounds it will, of course, be carried to fruition.

I remind honourable senators of the four powers. The Bill is based first and foremost on the external affairs power-in section 51 (xxix) of the Constitution, a power which has been used many times by different governments and which has seen expansion and development over the years. We know that governments, mostly of a conservative persuasion, have used it to develop aerial navigation. The powers which we have obtained in that area very largely come from genuine treaties that have been entered into on a world scale. They have enabled the Commonwealth to fill some defects and some gaps in the Constitution. At the turn of the century, when the Constitution was being formed, aerial navigation was not particularly prominent. The placitum has also been used for diplomatic legislation; it has been used in relation to the pollution of the sea by oil, in the Seas and Submerged Lands Act and, of course, most recently in the Koowarta v . Bjelke-Petersen case in which the Racial Discrimination Act was upheld by the High Court.

I have noticed in some of the arguments that have been used in the other chamber and elsewhere a regrettable tendency to quote only the Chief Justice, for whom I have great respect. However, the Chief Justice of the High Court happened to be in the minority in that case and therefore it is not his view which has prevailed; it is the view of the majority judges that should be quoted and that should be of great significance. I will quote two small extracts from those majority judgments because I believe it is amply demonstrated-I am sure it will be demonstrated in court-that this Bill is properly based on the external affairs power. It uses the power properly and this treaty that we have entered into is a genuine treaty. This is the answer to those people who talk about 16, 000 treaties. I think Dr Klugman, who is on the other side of the fence on this matter, has come up with some weird arguments in this area. He suggests that the Government might enter into a treaty with South Africa and introduce apartheid or some other unpleasant forms of life. Of course, one cannot misuse a treaty with another country to invoke the external affairs power. Obviously the treaty must be genuine. However, there is great width within the majority judgments in the Koowarta case for the expansion of the external affairs power which has accrued over many years. Page 50 of Mr Justice Mason's majority judgment states:

And I do not accept the suggestion that Australia's capacity to participate in world affairs would not be seriously inhibited. Increasing emphasis is given in the United Nations and in regional organisations to the pursuit by international treaties of idealistic and humanitarian goals. It is important that the Commonwealth should retain its full capacity through the external affairs power to represent Australia, to commit it to participation in these developments when appropriate and to give effect to obligations thereby undertaken.

Nor is there a solid foundation for implying a restriction that the treaty must relate to a matter which is international in character or of international concern, if the suggested restriction is intended to convey more than that the treaty is a genuine treaty. It is difficult to perceive why a genuine treaty, especially when it is multi-lateral and brought into existence under the auspices of the United Nations or an international agency, does not in itself relate to a matter of international concern and is not in itself an external affair.

Could not those words be said in relation to this Bill which is being debated in the chamber today? Perhaps I should quote from another judgment, that of Mr Justice Stephen, now the Governor-General. Although he takes a perhaps more moderate view on the extent of the external affairs power, he said:

The great post-war expansion of the areas properly the subject-matter of international agreement has, as Henkin points out and as J. A. Thompson emphasized in his article, at pp. 164-6, made it difficult indeed to identify subject-matters which are of their nature not of international but of only domestic conern-see also Howard, Australian Federal Constitutional Law (2nd ed., 1972) pp. 445-6. But this does no more than reflect the increasing awareness of the nations of the world that the state of society in other countries is very relevant to the State of their own society. Thus areas of what are of purely domestic concern are steadily contracting and those of international concern are ever expanding. Nevertheless the quality of being of international concern remains, no less than ever, a valid criterion of whether a particular subject- matter forms part of a nation's ''external affairs''.

I submit that there is no doubt about the international aspects of this matter, even on the slightly more limited view which Sir Ninian Stephen takes. I believe there can be no doubt that this Bill is rightly based firstly on that power.

I refer briefly to the other three powers. The foreign corporations power and the trading and financial corporations power, on which the legislation is likewise based, obviously give a great deal of power to the Bill and specific parts of the Bill are related to those powers. I refer also to the race power, the right to protect races and to make special laws in respect of particular races. Is there any doubt about the destruction of the early records of the Aboriginal people of this country and the great danger that they are in? This legislation is designed to ensure the protection of those records. I have no doubt that the special power in regard to race has great relevance to this legislation. Finally, I refer to the national power-the nationhood power-which is inherent in a nation and is incidental to its existence. It is the very power that was used to uphold the Australian Assistance Plan and, I think, is a further defence of this Bill.

I will not say anything very much about the Tasmanian attitude and the whole economic situation which is involved in the building of this dam which, I believe, should have never been contemplated. Last year I was denied the opportunity to speak in this chamber on the report of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania. I made a long statement on 21 December-I do not resile from one word of it-in which I set out my views that, of course, the Government should not proceed with a dam at this stage. I think that those matters have been well set out in the speech which Dr Harry Edwards made. After stating that the demand for power is so uncertain, he concluded:
. . . I can respond only by pointing out that to construct a dam for that purpose would surely be the most perverse and expensive make-work program one could possibly conceive.

If we read the evidence and see the lack of determination by the Tasmanian Government to investigate the various alternatives that are available we realise the very grave doubt that must be raised. The Honourable Barry Jones, in his speech in the other chamber, made it clear that the future for Tasmania obviously does not lie in this direction but in the direction of other developments that are likely to bring employment back into Tasmania. The Tasmanian Government is spending all its money on power and it has the highest level of unemployment, and the two facts are not coincidental. One needs also to read-I sent copies to all colleagues here-two excellent articles, which appeared in the Age, both written by Kenneth Davidson, the Age's finance writer, of 5 May and 9 May headed 'Parasites have gone too far' and 'Who pays makes dam national' . These articles have been quoted in this debate and they indicate the great extent to which the Australian people are paying excessive amounts of money to Tasmania, the extent to which the building of these dams will likely turn out to be unnecessary, how Tasmania will have its power sold off at ridiculous rates elsewhere and what that will do to other power users throughout Australia. I invite the reading of those articles because they indicate the financial folly of this move to which the Tasmanian Government has committed itself. That is perhaps not the issue mainly concerned with this Bill because the Australian people have voted and determined that the building of this dam should be stopped . Meanwhile the destruction goes on. Meanwhile the siting of the dam has not even been fixed because they are not even certain of where it can properly be put.

As Professor Mulvaney pointed out in a letter to Senator Don Chipp, a copy of which he sent me, there is also the fact that a coffer dam will have to be built , apparently within about three years, which will raise the level of the waters and destroy the archeological evidence forever. We do not hear Premier Gray talking about that matter. We do not hear anyone in Tasmania talking about that at the moment because, unfortunately, 10 years is not sufficient time for the testing of these things. It will be three years at best. Therefore there is urgency in stopping the building of the dam.

Let me say, turning to the Bill, that a number of Opposition amendments have been proposed. There are queries about the details of this Bill. These have been raised by both the committee of which I am Deputy Chairman, the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, and Opposition members. People from the Tasmanian Wilderness Society have also raised others. I hope that in reply the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) will perhaps indicate why he does not provide automatic protection for all the areas that are listed. There is the system of proclamations. Maybe it is to placate the susceptibilities of the States, I do not know, but I rather wonder why they are not at least automatically protected.

TALK.START.PARA: —We wanted it to survive challenge in the court, that is why. I will explain it.
—If that is a good reason--
—Prudence.

—If it is prudent, I will accept it. I also would like to know why he has gone beyond the listings and intended listings to the vaguer area of significant items which will never be applied for listing. It seems to me that the Bill did not need to go that far, but on the other hand if that is knocked down by the decision of the court not doubt it will not affect the rest of the Bill. In any event, if the Government endeavours to bring under this Bill items which should not be brought under it and makes regulations to that effect, of course they will be subject to disallowance by either House of the Parliament. I think there probably is adequate protection, but I query the reason it was done.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Opposition amendments in respect of substituting the Federal Court of Australia for the High Court of Australia in determining questions of compensation are valid. I am sorry that the Government so far has not accepted them. I likewise think that the provisions in respect of compensation have certain defects. People will no doubt in due course get their just terms but I wonder whether, if an item worth over $5m is determined by this special commission, the commission's report will be made available in the Parliament. Will it be tabled? Will we be able to see whether the Government has acted correctly or incorrectly in rejecting a claim and preferring some other means of compensation? Will the report be available during litigation? I believe that most think the report will be discoverable if there is a challenge in the Federal Court or in the High Court, but I would like to be sure that that is so. I believe there is some validity in a number of Opposition amendments which will have my support.

I make it clear that I support this Bill. I shall vote for it at the second reading stage and throughout its passage. I shall vote for a number of amendments because I believe they will improve the Bill. I shall support the Bill because I believe it is the obligation of Australians to do so. The Australian people have spoken. I note that we in the Opposition propose what is known as a pious amendment because it does not affect the second reading stage. The second part of that amendment, I think, is excellent because it suggests a better means of determining fair and reasonable compensation. But I would not agree to the first part of the amendment which suggests that we write into the legislation a provision that there must be a joint request by the State and Federal Parliaments before any further items are put upon the World Heritage List. I believe that has been the practice-it should continue to be the practice -but I do not think, in view of the destruction that could be done in some States at some time, that the Commonwealth should forgo its power in that way in the case of an emergency. On the other hand, I believe one ought to address these matters as a member of a nation, a nation with responsibilities. I believe we have accepted heavy responsibilities by signing the Convention and by listing these various areas. They are matters of great pride to the Australian people. They are of concern also to the people of the world. The people of the world are entitled to expect us to defend these areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who are the people of the world?
—'Who are the people of the world?', asks Senator Harradine. Senator Harradine would not know. He knows only the little spot where he gets a little support.
—I am asking you who are the people of the world.

—The people of the world are the ordinary people of the world and their descendants; they are entitled to know that wildernesses will be preserved , that we will not destroy or defile the whole of this planet but will protect it. We are in a world which is getting smaller and smaller and where damage to one part of it is damage to all of it.
—Ninety per cent are under dictatorships.
—I am not interested in Senator Harradine's cynicism. I am concerned with my obligations as a citizen of Australia, not just as a citizen of Victoria. Therefore, with that in mind--
—How many have a free Press?
—Ignoring the claptrap around us, I point out that I understand my obligations. I went to the electors, was re-endorsed and re-elected in Victoria. People knowing what--
—Where were you elected?
—I think it was seventh. I was No. 3 on my list. I was well endorsed and easily elected.
—You just scraped in-a short term senator.

—I am glad to be a short term senator. I therefore recognise the right of my constituents to expect me to vote according to conscience. Hundreds- indeed thousands-of people have indicated they want me to do so. I will do that, and therefore I will support this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill, and I do so for two reasons. The first reason is that I think it is essential to support many of the comments Senator Missen made when concluding his remarks on the Bill, and the second reason is that I think it is important to try to cut through the voluminous comments that have been made and the controversy that has been stirred up which clouds the fundamental and core issues as to why this Bill is necessary. I should say as well that my intervention in this debate will be short because most of the arguments have been put and also the passage of the Bill should not be slowed by continual laborious debate. The arguments are understood. I believe that we should get to the voting stage as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: My starting point in analysing the Bill is not to look at the Bill itself but to go to the United Nations Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage as set out in the attachment to the Bill. Article 2 of the Schedule, under the heading 'Definitions of the Cultural and the Natural Heritage', reads:
For the purposes of this Convention, the following shall be considered 'as natural heritage';
natural features consisting of physical and biological formations or groups of such formations, which are of outstanding universal value from the aesthetic or scientific point of view;

geological and physiographical formations and precisely delineated areas which constitute the habitat of threatened species of animals and plants of outstanding universal value from the point of view of science or conservation;
natural sites or precisely delineated natural areas of outstanding universal value from the point of view of science, conservation or natural beauty.

The purpose of the Bill, as we know, is to provide a means whereby areas of this country, once registered, can be protected under world heritage provisions. The areas that this Bill aims to cover are the Kakadu National Park, the Great Barrier Reef, the Willandra Lakes area and the South West Tasmania wilderness area.

These areas are to join 136 other properties on the World Heritage List- properties such as Yellowstone National Park in the United States, Serengeti National Park in Tanzania, the national park in Nepal of which Mount Everest is a part and the Great Barrier Reef. All those international features of geography make this world an interesting, varied and aesthetically appealing place. By introducing this Bill, we are trying to provide a means by which we can join in and have Australia's natural features preserved along with those that I have mentioned. To me, that is not something that we should be ashamed of. It is a matter of great pride that this continent has natural features that are worthy of inclusion alongside those I have mentioned-Yellowstone, Serengeti, Mount Everest, et cetera. Perhaps it is a feature of the Australian view that if it moves, shoot it or if it does not, cut it down, that we do not seem to accord such features the primacy that other countries do. It is interesting to contemplate-

TALK.START.PARA: —If it moves, sign it up.
—That might be the honourable senator's philosophy.
—No, it is the TWU philosophy.

—I am not sure what that has to do with this debate. It is interesting to note that, if Tasmania, the Northern Territory or any part of Australia had a gold medal winning Olympian, we would celebrate the achievement of that world conquering feat. We would praise the competitor and hold ticker- tape receptions and mayoral balls to celebrate the achievement. While we celebrate sporting achievements, we do no accord the same primacy to the natural features of this country. I cannot quite understand why there should be any controversy when it would seem to me that the natural view would be one of great pride that nature has chosen to adorn, amongst other places, South West Tasmania and make it one of the most unique creations on the face of the globe.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I make is that the Australian Labor Party has a mandate for this legislation. There is no question that it figures prominently as a key issue in the election campaign. That is a matter of common knowledge. Anyone who reads any number of the pot boilers that were churned out which analysed the election results will see that all the pundits concurred in the view that the Australian electorate supported legislation to protect South West Tasmania. It seems to me that the conflict, expressed in its barest form, is a conflict between what the overwhelming majority of people of Australia, as a united federation, want and what the majority in a region think is suitable for them. If one analyses the question in the face of that sort of conflict and asks whose rights should prevail, one comes to the clear conclusion that, if the vast majority of the community conflicts with a minority in one area, given certain protections of the minority, the majority right ought to prevail.

If I were to move away from the controversy that has raged about this legislation and give an example, I could cite the case of a worker who makes money painting chocolate box tops. In a corner of his store he finds the original Mona Lisa gathering dust. He wants to expand his chocolate box top painting industry and he needs more material, so he decides to clean off the old oils that clog the canvas of the Mona Lisa in order to make more material. Everyone who uses his store complains that that is a desecration of something of value that cannot be reproduced anywhere. The question is: Who has the right? Does the chocolate box tops painter have the right to destroy an artefact that is recognised universally as being of outstanding merit, or does everyone else who appreciates its value have the right to say that it shall not be destroyed?

Where such conflict occurs, the first obligation on all parties is to negotiate an acceptable solution. In regard to this legislation, the former Fraser Government attempted to do that. It offered $500m, as an alternative to proceeding with the project, to ensure that the damming did not go ahead. The Australian Labor Party, under the leadership of Bill Hayden and after the election under the leadership of Bob Hawke, attempted to negotiate with the Tasmanian Government. These were reasonable, rational attempts to come to grips with certain needs in Tasmania that do exist and that have to be recognised. The fact that the reasonable approach at negotiation is militantly rejected means, I think, that a determination between each of the competing rights-the right of the region or of the country-has to be made. In its final decision, that determination turns on what is the greater good for the greatest number.

As has been said in the earlier contribution to this debate by Senator Missen- it was also referred to in the second reading speech-there are four independent heads of Commonwealth power under which the Commonwealth can move. They are the external affairs power, the corporations power, the race power and the nationhood power. Those powers can rightly be seen in the context of providing instruments which give effect to the moral power whereby, in a case of this sort , the rights of the overall community should prevail, given that the overall community has made an attempt to come to grips with the needs of the region concerned. If the region then rejects those attempts and militantly slams the door in the face of the reasonable approach, the determination should be made in moral right. I hope that the legislation can be seen in those terms. As I said at the beginning, I think it proper that my contribution be short and to the point to enable this legislation's passage to be complete. I do not support the amendments. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill 1983. It is regrettable that this Bill not only has divided the nation but also has divided families. I think it is regrettable also that the issues surrounding this Bill are far wider than might be suggested. They involve not merely the building of the dam; what is now envisaged is States' rights. The Bill tends to alter the Australian federal system by back door methods. It seeks to alter the balance between the States and that between the States and the Federal Government. This is normally done through a referendum, but the Government is seeking to change these various rights by an Act of Parliament. The issue is now seen by many outsiders as a struggle similar to that between David and Goliath. We all know where world sympathy lies in such a struggle between unequal partners.

SPEECH.PARA: I only hope that the High Court of Australia follows the precedents that have been set by its counterpart in the United States of America which throughout its history has upheld the purpose of the federation. Any change to that philosophy by our High Court would, I think, be regrettable. Any such change would mean a tremendous increase in the powers and the functions of any State government. This Bill seeks to usurp the rights of the States. I believe that the Tasmanian Premier Robin Gray, in just 12 months in office, has done more to hold back socialism and centralism than has any other government in the Commonwealth in the past 20 years. The Bill involves the giving up of State powers not only to a central government but also to an outside organisation. I believe this is a dangerous precedent.

Although I am unhappy about the Bill, I think the careful wording of Senator Martin's amendment which requires that the listings be requested by both State and Federal parliaments, overcomes a loophole which was cleverly exploited by the former Premier of Tasmania, Doug Lowe. The Federal Government says that the nomination for the listing was made by the Tasmanian Government. I believe this is a slight exaggeration, unless decisions by one man mean government. After last week's announcement of the royal commission concerning the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, perhaps the Federal Government believes that the judiciary provides a legitimate way of making important decisions. But no evidence has ever been offered contrary to what my colleague Senator Missen said today about openess of the decision-making process in relation to this issue. No evidence has ever been offered to show how the former Premier Lowe discussed the matter in Cabinet or Caucus. Certainly, there has been no evidence to show how he discussed it in parliament. That could not be construed as open, honest government as such.

Although the World Heritage Commission currently has 136 properties from 36 countries on its list, I am concerned that there will be tremendous problems in accepting the World Heritage Conservation Bill because of its wide-ranging nature. Clause 6 (2) states:
A proclamation may be made . . . in relation to an identified property . . .

(d) the protection or conservation of the property by Australia is a matter of international concern . . . whether by reason that a failure by Australia to take proper measures for the protection or conservation of the property would, or would be likely to, prejudice Australia's relations with other countries . . .

That provision means that although there may be no local concern about an issue, the Federal Government could proclaim a particular area because a David Bellamy or somebody from outside believes that it may raise an international concern or because he may exert some pressure.

This legislation has tremendous implications for the whole of Australia. It is a very wide-ranging Bill. I think it ranges far too widely for this Senate to accept. Further, we have a very wide provision in clause 11. It lists certain unlawful acts in relation to Aboriginal sites. We know that there are literally hundreds of Aboriginal cairns in the area of the west coast of Tasmania and that there are thousands throughout the whole of Australia. Some are of great significance to the nation; others are of very much less importance. The clause does not indicate the extent of the importance or the nature of a particular cairn, relic or area. It does not say how far away from the centre of the area its provisions apply. We will run into tremendous legalistic problems as to the extent of action in these areas. The Bill is far too wide-ranging for practical application.

I can see the provisions of clause 11 being used to thwart almost any major mining development not only in Tasmania but also in the whole of Australia. So I say to the mining developers in Australia: 'Look out, because your ability to exploit your mine to its full potential could be severely affected as a result of the provisions of clause 11'. Tasmania, particularly the west coast, is rich in minerals. It has tremendous potential. We will find the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act being used time and again to thwart development in such areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that your party's policy?

—I think it essential that we preserve significant Aboriginal areas, but I think we have to recognise that there are many hundreds of cairns in that area, as the honourable senator, being a scientist, would well know. Some of them are of fairly minor significance. I think we must acknowledge that. The potential of this legislation to stop mining development is very significant .

SPEECH.PARA: It worries me that some radical elements have tended to take over the Australian conservation movement. A suggestion was put forward-I think I raised it in the Senate about 18 months ago-about the Anthony-Henty scheme. Bob Hawke mentioned it as an alternative. But what has happened? The Tasmanian Wilderness Society and the conservation movement have stated that although the area in question is outside the defined wilderness area they will oppose its development . I think we will see any future hydro-electric development in Tasmania come under this umbrella of criticism from this narrowly vested radical group which I believe has been infiltrated in some sectors by the more radical anti- development elements.

Unfortunately, Tasmania does not have the alternatives to which the other States can turn. Hydro-electric development under the scheme that is envisaged in the South West is undoubtedly the cheapest. I think it is unfortunate that the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania, in its report, showed some bias in selecting the least favourable projections on a fairly consistent basis, but I do not think that excuses us from opposing the legislation. I think we should therefore oppose the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill. We have to look at this issue from a practical point of view. Tasmania needs the energy. It is unfortunate that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has not demonstrated publicly the alternatives to the construction of the dam or the extent of the compensation. It is, therefore, no wonder that the Tasmanian people are somewhat cynical and concerned about the issue. 'Reconciliation' and 'reconstruction' are very hollow words in relation to what we have seen in recent times with regard to South West Tasmania. The Government is ignoring the expressed wishes of Tasmanians. It has resorted to enacting regulations which have not been debated. Legal opinion has indicated that some of those regulations may not be acceptable to the High Court. We are now faced with this Bill. It is unfortunate that we have reached this impasse. The external affairs powers of the Commonwealth, as stated in the Constitution, were never intended to block a State domestic public works program. The people of Tasmania have shown that they have the right to make this internal decision by themselves.

The Tasmanian Government cannot be accused of taking the decision lightly. There has been lengthy discussion in the State Parliament. In the referendum held in December 1981, a majority voted for the construction of the dam. In the State election held in May 1982 two anti-dammers were elected. I believe that the Hare-Clarke system is very fair and gives the best opportunity for proportional representation, including representation of the minority groups. But those groups were soundly defeated. In March 1983 there was an overwhelming endorsement of the decision in Tasmania. We retained not only the five House of Representatives seats, but also our five Senate positions. We were given increased support. Many Labor people, particularly on the west coast, for the first time in their lives voted for the Liberal Party. They were concerned, and I am concerned, about jobs.

The extent of the compensation that has been offered is limited merely to Hydro -Electric Commission employees. That does not include the hundreds of self- employed people working on the site, all those people who have entered into tremendous hire purchase and leasing commitments for specialised equipment to be used in that area. Those people will be declared bankrupt if the dam does not go ahead. There is to be no compensation for them. What about compensation for firms such as Goliath Portland Cement Co. Ltd and all the other firms which are providing materials? Again, it is regrettable that we have not had a clear statement of the alternatives that should have been and could have been offered at a far earlier stage than this. We are still waiting. Is it any wonder that the Tasmanian people are fairly cynical on this issue?

Employment is needed in Tasmania. The thermal power station option would be fairly costly, if not impossible. The quality of Tasmanian coal is not very high . The importation of coal from the mainland would be subject to the industrial disputations that occur within the coal industry and in the maritime unions. It would be difficult to site the power station in or near a port which is not in an environmentally sensitive area. A suggestion has been made to site it in Bell Bay. But local opinion in that area is against this proposal, because Bell Bay, in the Tamar Valley, has problems with fog. A thermal station sited there would cause a tremendous smog problem. The siting of the station in a suitable area near a port and importing coal from the mainland, would be difficult and costly.

In the last day we have seen a 30 per cent increase in the cost of natural gas to manufacturers in Victoria. This is one example of the cost of alternatives. Tasmania does not have alternatives. We must rely on hydro-electric power. Will the opponents of the dam permanently place Tasmania in such a position that it will never be any more than a tourist State? Because of the climatic conditions, tourism is essentially seasonal.

The Bill lacks adequate compensation provisions. The debate and the delay could go on for six years. The Bill contains nothing about adequate compensation and the extent to which the State would be assisted by the Commonwealth Government. We need definite answers, before this debate is concluded, to satisfy the Tasmanian people that they will not be held to ransom. I oppose the Bill and I hope my colleagues will do likewise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also oppose the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill 1983. I do so without any qualms whatsoever. To agree to legislation such as this would be giving away Tasmania's right to determine its destiny in development. It would be a serious interference with our State rights . The people of Tasmania have certainly shown over the last few years that they want the dam and development in South West Tasmania to go ahead. It has already been pointed out that 51 of the 54 members of the Parliament of Tasmania voted for the dam and the power scheme to be developed. That is almost a unanimous vote. I imagine that the only vote nearer to a unanimous vote would concern a pay rise.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last election the people of Tasmania very solidly supported Robin Gray because he was in favour of the building of the dam. The Government has attempted to stop the dam by bringing in amendments or regulations under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 and by bringing this Bill before the Parliament. This is one of the reasons why it is already in trouble. Its priorities are wrong. The statement by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, that he believes in consensus and conciliation, has already been shown to be completely wrong by his actions on the dam.

TALK.START.PARA: —He tried.

—So did Mr Fraser try. The point is that Mr Hawke's priorities are wrong. Why on earth should he try to interfere with what a Tasmanian government almost unanimously wants, what a Tasmanian parliament almost unanimously wants and what he wants?
—We have a responsibility to our electors.

—Rubbish! Let me assure honourable senators that the people of Tasmania do not like the intervention of the Prime Minister in this matter. I agree that some people are against the building of the dam; I know many of them. But I believe that the majority of people are in favour of it, and I would like to think they show a considerable amount of sense. If one looks at the future of Tasmania one does not have to be an Einstein to work out that if more power is needed it has to come from such a scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: I have made my position quite clear on this matter previously. The generation of electricity by atomic energy is not practicable; it really has to be done on a big scale to be feasible and to keep the price of each unit down. In addition, I believe that the tremendous difficulty of dealing with the waste has yet to be solved. I know that some people think that Synroc, developed by the Australian National University, will be of some use, but I still do not believe the problem has been solved to the extent that it needs to be before we can build an atomic power station in this country. Anyway, what would be the attitude of people such as those in the Tasmanian Wilderness Society and those who live on some of the Tasmanian islands if we attempted to put an atomic power station in some of those areas? I think I should mention another point about atomic power stations. At their present stage of development they are very complex installations. They have very large control rooms which are comparable with the size of this chamber . To put the people who operate them, who have to be very well trained, in a very remote area is not a practical solution. That is just one point that always has to be borne in mind when we even think about atomic power stations.

I turn to the question of damage to the environment. Perhaps the most damaging thing that could be done would be to build a coal-burning power station. I am advised that quite a lot of uranium falls out of the smokestacks of such places and that that certainly cannot be controlled; and there is acid rain and so on. As Senator Watson said, if such a station were put in the foggy Tamar area it would not do very much for the environment of the area. We can discount an oil- fired power station very simply because of its cost. To bring a power cable across Bass Strait from the mainland to Tasmania is not practical. As I have said before, that would cost probably about $600m and it would be twice as long as any existing undersea cable anywhere in the world. Just the cost of that would make it prohibitive. Solar power and wind power which some honourable senators have mentioned are not reliable enough or proven enough even to bear consideration at this stage of development.

As I see it, a hydro-electric scheme is the best scheme. Hydro-electric dams could be built in other places, but from the information I have, I believe the present dam will produce power at the most reasonable cost. We have to remember that the people who plan the use of power in Tasmania in their estimation of whether we will need power have calculated an increase of only 2.7 per cent per annum. That is a fairly small increase; it has been much more than that over the last few years. Seventy per cent of the power to be produced by the dam will go to commercial, domestic and light industry users and 30 per cent will go to, I think, 19 contractors whom we could class as heavy industry.

It is my great belief that this dam should be built. The issue has been debated for many years. Quite obviously this Bill will enable Canberra to impose its will on some of the States, which I think not only Tasmania but also other States may live to regret. It may also allow people internationally to impose their wills on Australia. I do not believe that the international view is more important than the national view, and I will not agree that Canberra should have overriding power over Tasmania. Countries involved in ratifying decisions which are submitted to the World Heritage Committee include Iran, Iraq, Yugoslavia, Poland, Cuba and Ethiopia. I could go on. They are not countries which should be telling the people of Tasmania what development they will go ahead with. I believe that by developing that area of Tasmania many more people than would otherwise be the case will have an opportunity to see it. The area is not a bushwalking area-it never has been-and it is not virgin forest; it was logged many years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it was not massacred as it is being now.
—Has the honourable senator been there recently?
—About 12 months ago.

—The point is that when the honourable senator did go there, how did she get there? If the dam were built then an access road would obviously have to be built; and if that were done in a reasonable way, thousands of people who otherwise would not be able to get there would be able to do so. I was against the flooding of Lake Pedder for a mechanical reason. Lake Pedder was flooded not to get extra water but because water had to be siphoned from one area to another and the easiest and least expensive way of doing that was to lift the level of the whole lake. Had a siphon been built at a cost of about $2m , the old Lake Pedder, which I enjoyed very much, would have been left in its original state. Having been to the new Lake Pedder, having seen the number of people who go there, having talked to some of them and having heard the reports they give of it, I would say that for me to have wanted it left as it was rather than being changed would have been a selfish view. That is how I think this whole matter is turning out. The people of the mainland of Australia are trying to use an international agreement to control what the people of Tasmania want. That is something I will not stand for. I will be supporting the proposed amendments to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was with considerable pride that I heard earlier this year the announcement of an offer consistent with Liberal Party policy for the preservation and development of a world standard park in South West Tasmania. The former Government offered $500m negotiable, plus $50m towards a management plan. That was consistent with a policy which in 1974-75 I had participated in developing. I regret, as I shall point out, that things have not worked out as I would like them to have done. I did not support, and do not support, a thermal power station in the Tamar Valley. I was the only honourable senator who chose to give evidence to the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania. I indicated in that evidence that I believed it would be criminally insane to provide a thermal power station in that valley. Yet I find that such is the head of steam which has been developed in relation to the issue of thermal power stations that I am accused of advocating a thermal power station for the Tamar Valley. It already has a temperature inversion problem. It does not need to have that problem exacerbated by a coal-fixed thermal power station. I would not have built any sort of thermal power station in that valley if I had had a say in it.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, I took the trouble to give evidence to the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania. That evidence was the product of many years of study and experience of, amongst other things, the accountability of statutory authorities , of economics, of the financing of electricity generation, of the tourism industry and policy development in relation to tourism and, I hope, a rational concern for the environment as well as a fairly deep knowledge of South West Tasmania which I fear that a number of the other people involved in this debate do not appear to reflect. I have the best interests of my beautiful State of Tasmania at heart when I say that I regard what has now developed as one of the matters for great regret. Opinions may vary, and I believe that we are all entitled to our opinions. The opinion I have and which I hold very deeply is the result of not only love, knowledge and experience but also an attempt to combine those factors in the development of something which is rational and possible. I adhere entirely to what I said in evidence to the Senate Committee and in speaking in this chamber last December.

On the economics of the proposal for further hydro-electric development is Tasmania, I believe that the debate has gone past the stage where it is a matter of great relevance. The parties have chosen the path to the High Court and the economics or otherwise of the proposal are not relevant to that path. Let me cite certain figures which I think may help if they are put on the record. An impression has been given in relation to Tasmania and the relative size of its national parks and conservation areas. The geography of Tasmania is such that it has a large number of sensitive highland areas which in any country would be national parks. It is not the real world to suggest an undue amount is reserved when the fact is that 13.4 per cent of the State-this includes Macquarie Island which has an interesting history relevant, perhaps, to some lessons that might have been learnt in relation to this issue-is national park or the equivalent where no other statutory powers apply. Macquarie Island represents 1.4 per cent of that park land. A further 10 per cent of conservation areas are subject to certain controls but timber cutting, hydro-electric development, mining, et cetera, may be carried out. So, when we hear talk of 23.4 per cent of the State being reserved for national parks, that is not strictly accurate. Thirteen point four per cent of the State is reserved as a national park and a further 10 per cent is classed as conservation areas, quite a large part of which is in the highland country which has been protected from undue use for grazing and from tracks being run all over it because of its sensitivity to erosion and similar problems. It is subject to a management plan and is available for most purposes. So I think some slight misunderstanding is sometimes created when such figures are cited.

Another factor which has been referred to a number of times is the circumstances of the listing by the World Heritage Committee in relation to the application for South West Tasmania. Professor Ralph Slatyer, writing in the recent edition of the Heritage Newsletter, Volume 6, No. 1, March 1983, says:
It has been suggested that, knowing that dam construction has commenced, the committee's action in listing South-west Tasmania condoned the dam project. This was definitely not the case.
He then went on to quote:
'The Committee recommends that the Australian authorities take all possible measures to protect the integrity of the property.'
He went on to say a little later:
It amounts to a plea to the Tasmanian and Australian Governments to find an alternative to dam construction so that this magnificent area can be protected and conserved-

I do not wish to say that from the point of view of encouraging further debate about that aspect but simply to place on the record what Professor Slatyer, the leader of the Australian delegation and the Chairman of the World Heritage Committee, had to say about the circumstances.

In regard to the compensation question, which I believe will be debated in greater depth during the Committee stage of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill 1983, I simply say that at no stage in my thoughts and my attempt at development of a policy in relation to this matter was there ever any contemplation that the State of Tasmania would not be compensated properly and fairly, in relation to any development of a world heritage national park in South West Tasmania. I believe that there are shortcomings in this Bill which can be debated during the Committee stage.

The division of society in Tasmania has been tragic. It will take many years to heal. Such divisions are the result of the failure of all parties to adhere to the policy which was developed in 1975. Had that course been followed by the various governments of various political colours, the problems would have been avoided. I believe it is to be regretted that those divisions were heightened by actions taken both by the Tasmanian Wilderness Society and the Hydro-Electric Commission unions and contractors' organisations, which is known as the Organisation for Tasmanian Development. Blockades, demonstrations, marches and the like are neither the vehicles nor the handmaidens of democracy. Political parties, families, friendships, business and union relationships have all been placed under tremendous strain. I do not wish to do anything to exacerbate those divisions. I have tried to see a balance in not only the resources of nature and their exploitation but also the political approach. In 1975 I thought I had succeeded. In 1983 I must admit that I have failed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A torrent of words has been spoken in this debate and on numerous preceding occasions when the South West Tasmania issue has been debated. I do not believe that I can do very much more in reply than to state the essence of the debate from our point of view in language which was used in the course of the election campaign by the present Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, when he said that the destruction of South West Tasmania would be 'both an environmental obscenity and an economic absurdity'. I think that phrase encapsulates precisely the nub of the dual objection that is felt and experienced by not only those people on this side of the House but also a great majority of Australians as to what is going on down there. The World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill 1983, of course, necessarily has its most immediate impact in the context of South West Tasmania, although equally obviously it has been drafted to be available for the protection of areas of Australia's cultural and natural heritage that demand protection generally and are not getting it from the States.

SPEECH.PARA: In reply I want to deal with no more than three different matters; the two issues that are raised in the Opposition's second reading amendment and, finally , the matter that was raised by Senator Missen from the left, as it were, representing perhaps the extreme environmental position in which he sought an explanation as to why it was that the Bill was not directed in terms so as to have immediate application to at least all those areas on the World Heritage List without requiring the necessity for government proclamations.

Let me address myself quite swiftly then to these various different matters. The first criticism that is involved in the second reading amendment moved by the Opposition is that it urges that the Bill be amended in such a way as to require it in effect to operate only when there is a joint application for the listing of a property on the World Heritage List by the State and the Commonwealth. In other words, this legislation is to have no application other than in circumstances where there is complete identity of approach and attitude between the Commonwealth and the State-presumably also the Territory-where the property in question is. This, of course, goes to the nub of so much of the argument that we have experienced during this debate about the supposed overweening reach of Commonwealth power. I simply make this very important point on that argument: The legislation is not drafted in any way so as to attract to the Commonwealth the power of control and management of areas of State and Territory property, except in circumstances where that property is capable of clear identification as being of outstanding, universal significance and, in addition, where that property is under threat, in situations where it is likely to be destroyed or damaged. This applies in situations where the State in question has abdicated its responsibility to the world community, the national community and indeed its own members within the State. Only in those circumstances is the Commonwealth claiming the capacity to exercise the power to intervene to protect the area in question. The need for the Commonwealth to have this capacity, quite apart from the question of its power to do so, must be amply demonstrated by the course of events in relation to the South West Tasmanian dam.

It has been suggested on various occasions, rather faintly for the most part, that, at least since the change of government, the Commonwealth has not seriously sought consensus with the Government of Tasmania; that it has made no real attempts to offer alternatives to that State to compensate for the Gordon below Franklin Dam not going ahead. The facts, of course, are to the contrary and show that our record not only is consistent and entirely sensible but also has been publicly demonstrated over and over again to be so. Our pre-election commitment, which we have sustained throughout the whole tortuous course of this affair, was not only to oppose the construction of the hydro-electric power scheme on the Gordon below Franklin River for economic and environmental reasons but also to provide assistance to the Tasmanian Government to enable it to diversify, or extend by other means, its energy production and to ensure the economic livelihood of those who might otherwise be employed as a result of the dam proceeding.

As we all know, the question of the dam was one of the really significant issues in the election campaign extending in its public interest to the whole of Australia. We believe that we have a clear mandate from the people of Australia to act; we are so acting. The Opposition has claimed, occasionally noisily, that the Bill is anti-people. Our view is that the stance taken by the Government in this Bill is pro-people in that it reflects a concern, endorsed by the majority of Australians, in returning us to power. Since the election, we have consistently attempted to get Premier Gray to the negotiating table with a conspicuous lack of success which is now notorious and hardly needs to be detailed. The threat to the environment there is clear. The international significance of the area is clear. There is no other way that that area will be protected except by Commonwealth action and that is exactly what is now involved .
The second point in the second reading amendment moved by the Opposition is an attempt to focus on the purported failure of the Government to:
. . . develop adequate procedures for the provision of fair and reasonable compensation to States, corporations or individuals whose property may be the subject of proclamation under the Act.

Since this matter undoubtedly will be the subject of some discussion during the Committee stage of this debate, I will try to pre-empt some of that debate by stating as succinctly as I can what this Bill does and does not do as far as the compensation issue is concerned. Certainly, there is no attempt within the four corners of this Bill to lay out in any way the procedures whereby any appropriate compensation to Tasmania of the kind that the Commonwealth has been promising throughout the whole attempt at negotiations in this area would be determined. This Bill does not in any way seek to establish procedures which would pre-empt the process of consultation and negotiation-horse trading-by which an acceptable compensation package involving not just purely formal legal criteria but also the whole political complex of economic and social criteria can be taken into account. The Bill is not in any way attempting to reach into that area of a possible final negotiated compensation solution in the event that the dam either is built or is not built. The Bill is essentially silent on that subject. It is not to the point to criticise the legislation for not anticipating that and somehow dealing with it.

Nor-this is getting closer to the sort of technical legal points that will occupy us in the Committee stage-does the Bill expressly provide in any way for the land that is the subject of the operation of this Bill to be acquired by the Commonwealth. This is not a Bill which makes explicit provision for the acquisition of threatened property. It is not some sort of attempted and less detailed rewrite of the existing Commonwealth Lands Acquisition Act. The Bill, on its face, does not make provision or establish procedures for the acquisition of land. If the Commonwealth wants to acquire land, whether it be the Franklin River valley or anywhere else in the country that satisfies the criteria of this legislation, the Commonwealth would need to do so-assuming that it had the constitutional power and it was within the purposes of the Commonwealth- employing the procedures of the Lands Acquisition Act. All that this Bill does is tackle one exotic situation that may arise in the course of the implementation of this Bill. This has been totally misunderstood in most of the debates so far.

What the Bill is getting at in the provisions which purport to deal with compensation is simply this: If, by the exercise of one or more of the prohibitory powers contained in this Bill-the powers to stop the construction of dams or roads or whatever-the Commonwealth so interferes with the use and enjoyment of the land in question by its owner or occupier that the court is moved to find that that amounts to an acquisition of land, under those circumstances a procedure is set out for the determination of appropriate compensation. There is a considerable degree of uncertainty in the law whether a really extensive set of prohibitions by a government in relation to the use and occupancy of land could amount to an acquisition in a technical, legal sense or for the purpose in particular in section 51 placitum (xxxi) of the Constitution which says that, where there is an acquisition of land by the Commonwealth, just terms have to be provided. This Bill simply attempts to anticipate the possibility that the exercise of these powers, even though the Commonwealth has no intention of acquiring the land in question, would be construed by the Court, notwithstanding that absence of intention, as being an acquisition.

In dealing with that situation, the Bill goes on to lay out a procedure. It says that, where the sum in question-that is, the amount that is in issue by virtue of this course of events-is less than $5m, claims of this kind will be dealt with by the Federal Court. If it is more than $5m, provision is made for a commission of inquiry to be established. The reason why a commission of inquiry is to be established, in short, rather than simply leaving it to the court or to the procedures of the Lands Acquisition Act is that we are talking about very different situations from those that normally arise under the Lands Acquisition Act where the Commonwealth is purchasing land for a defence rifle range, the erection of a post office or something of that kind.

For example, we are talking about the possibility that what happens in South West Tasmania will be construed under the Constitution as amounting to an acquisition of land. When it comes to compensation that will raise very real questions related to the whole economic future of Tasmania-matters which are not usually within the compass of courts and are certainly not dealt with by using the procedures of the Lands Acquisition Act which the Opposition, in the amendments which it has foreshadowed, would have us regard as thoroughly applicable to that situation. One could go into a lot more detail about that. I will save it all up for the Committee stage if it is necessary to use it in the Committee stage. I hope that in the light of that explanation the Opposition will change its attitude to some of the whole series of amendments which are based on a quite different theory here, that what is involved is something that is a denial of the rights of individuals of the kind they have under the existing Lands Acquisition Act.

Another point I make, and make very briefly, is the sort of point that Senator Missen was making and that a lot of the environmentalists have continued to make ; that is, a concern about why this Bill does not, on its face, immediately apply at least to all the World Heritage listed land and maybe to all other land that can satisfy the criteria of being part of the nation's cultural and natural heritage. There are two reasons basically why the Bill is not expressed to have automatic application of this kind. The first one is obviously that to give the Bill automatic application in this way, without a prior course of consultation and negotiation with the States or Territories in question, would be not an exercise in comity, not an exercise in good government. The reality is that there has not been such a course of negotiation in the context of the Great Barrier Reef with Queensland; the Willandra Lakes and so on with New South Wales ; and Kakadu with the Northern Territory. There has not needed to be. But there has not been, and for that reason the Commonwealth would not wish here and now to have the Bill automatically applicable in that way.

The other reason, which I hope will be appreciated, is a profoundly important constitutional one.
