We are anxious to enhance the constitutional chances of this Bill surviving scrutiny before the High Court of Australia and we believe that it will enhance its chances of being upheld as constitutionally valid if it is drafted in the way that it is, rather than being automatically applicable to anything in sight which potentially satisfies the description of World Heritage property. The way the Bill is drafted at the moment, it is applicable and the Commonwealth can act only where the land in question or the property in question is under threat. In other words, the States are given a fighting chance to go in and protect the property themselves before the Commonwealth, in the exercise of its obligations under the external affairs power or otherwise, in fact is entitled to move in. We believe that the provisions should be couched in those terms. I hope Senator Missen will appreciate this and I hope every one else who has been critical of the Bill for its supposed weakness in this respect will appreciate the force of the point I am making.
Thousands of other points could be made in response to the issues that have been canvassed during the debate. I do not think this is the time or place to rehearse them once again.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 and 2-by leave-taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill is incorrectly named. Only a few clauses have relevance. The Bill is far broader than the World Heritage Convention and many of the clauses have absolutely nothing to do with the Convention, any treaties or indeed anything else at all. Most of the Bill refers to 'for any other reason' and includes anything that has come to the present Government's head. I stress my concern that this Bill has been so named in an effort to get across to the people of Australia that really it is about nothing except the dam in the South West of Tasmania. It is, I believe, most important that the people of Australia realise that this Bill has nothing to do with the dam except in some very peripheral sense. It has to do with this Government taking a grab at any area in any State which it so desires. This can be seen in clause 6. No doubt this clause will be discussed at a later stage. I will have words on that clause then . I believe that this Bill ought to be renamed. I appeal to the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) to explain to me exactly why this Bill is so named.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find myself in agreement with Senator Walters on this matter. I think that the short title, the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, is most inappropriate. So far as I can see, the Bill is a heritage Bill only in the sense that it tramples on the heritage of our civil rights and liberties. I draw the attention of the Committee to the fact that the intention of the Bill-despite its wording-is to stop development in South West Tasmania as determined by the properly elected Parliament of Tasmania. I emphasise the word 'Parliament', because I take a different point of view from that of the Premier of Tasmania on quite a number of issues. The fact of life is that the decision has been made by those persons who have the information and the responsibility to make that decision; namely, the members of the State Parliament of Tasmania. We should bear in mind that honourable senators, particularly the newly elected senators, do not realise that the original proposal put forward by the Hydro-Electric Commission was not accepted by the State Parliament of Tasmania, including the members of the Legislative Council. The middle Franklin scheme was not accepted by the State Parliament of Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: As I mentioned at the second reading stage, the members of the State Parliament are concerned as Australians and as Tasmanians about the environment of Tasmania as well as its development. The Liberal Party members of the Tasmanian Parliament, the bulk of the Australian Labor Party members of the Tasmanian Parliament and the bulk of the Independent members of the Tasmanian Parliament, came to the conclusion that the development should take place. This Bill, particularly where it relies on the external affairs power of clause 51 (xxix) of the Constitution, seeks to override that decision. In so doing it attempts to impose a regime which will be detrimental to the heritage of our civil liberties . I ask that the Committee bear this fact in mind in considering the first clause which is before us; namely, the short title of the Bill, the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983.

I emphasise the point that, contrary to what Senator Missen said when he appealed to us to have regard to what the peoples of the world have to say about it, the peoples of the world do not have any say in 80 to 90 per cent of the countries that are signatories to the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage. It is a matter of fact that only 30 of the 150 countries that make up the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation have a free Press. Therefore, the majority of people in those countries would not know what the issues were. We, as a democratic parliament, are being asked to pass what is called a world heritage Bill, a Bill which appeals to the people of the world who, firstly, do not have any democratic rights and, secondly, have no responsibility for what happens in Tasmania.

I simply ask: Who is to be responsible in the final analysis if this Bill is successful and is upheld by the High Court of Australia? Who is to be responsible when the lights go out in Tasmania? Who is to be responsible when workers in Tasmania are stood down in the not too distant future as a result of lack of power? I certainly will be asking the question at that time. I wonder whether the people who are supporting this measure will be able to stand up and say: 'Yes, I am responsible for you losing pay as a result of the fact that there is not enough electricity to provide for the operation of the industry in which you are employed. Yes, I am responsible for the lights going out. I am responsible for the tea not being cooked'. I am just waiting for that day to occur. I will then remind those who support this measure of what I have said today. I fully expect them to be man and woman enough to stand up and be counted at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have concerns about the purpose, the intent and also the naming of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill. On the face of it this Bill appears to have some very laudable objectives. But behind this facade we see it as really being an attack on the States and a mechanism whereby the power and control of central government will be significantly enhanced. This Bill is certainly a manifestation of what we might term single issue politics in Australia. It is a back door method by which to alter the balance of powers between the Commonwealth and the States. We are using a mechanism which I believe was never envisaged by the founding fathers of the Constitution. I believe that despite all the laudable objectives that might appear to exist it is not the right way to go-to attack the sovereign rights of an independent State. I think history will show that this is, indeed, a bad Bill .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —To the extent that it is necessary to reply briefly to comments about the inappropriateness or otherwise of the title of the Bill, I simply say that it is an appropriate title because the whole thrust of the Bill is directed towards property which, in turn, has to satisfy the description of either 'cultural heritage' or 'natural heritage'. The definitions of those terms, in turn, are established by a reference to the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage. So the whole thrust of the Bill throughout is geared to the language of the Convention and the principles embodied in it, which refer to areas of cultural and natural heritage which are of outstanding universal value. So the concept of universality or world-wide significance is very much built into the operating criteria of this Bill. I hope that what might be thought to be legitimate criticism of the Bill can be answered in those terms.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Chairman-I hope it will not be necessary to make this point too often-I draw your attention to the necessity for Committee stage debate to proceed by close reference to the terms of the particular clauses which we are debating. Whilst I have no wish to deny Senator Harradine his, it is hoped, dying oratorical flourish in his last contribution, it did not bear awfully much resemblance to the title of the Bill. I hope that strict adherence to the rules of debate can be enforced from the Chair from now on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Evans. I was listening to Senator Harradine with close attention. He was skirting the boundaries, but just staying within them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I am quite sure that we are all very grateful to Senator Evans for his little lecture to you. I ask that he please stick to the questions that are asked of him. Senator Evans said that the wording of the name of this Bill has to do with cultural and natural heritage. I would like him to explain this to me. I am sorry that I have to refer to clause 6 (d) now but it brings me to question the naming of this Bill. The Minister says it relates to anything that has to do with natural and cultural heritage. It has nothing to do with that, as I see it, because it is-
—Which clause is it?
—It is clause 6 (2) (d), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The protection or conservation of the property by Australia is a matter of international concern (whether or not it is also a matter of domestic concern)--
Really it does not matter whether the people want it. It is the Government's worry whether it is of international concern. It is not worried about local concern. The clause goes on to state:

whether by reason that a failure by Australia to take proper measures for the protection or conservation of the property would, or would be likely to, prejudice Australia's relations with other countries or for any other reason;
Nothing in that paragraph deals with natural heritage or cultural heritage. I ask Senator Evans whether he could possibly relate that clause to cultural and natural heritage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be absolutely delighted to do what Senator Walters asks. If she casts her eyes to the top of page 3 of the Bill she will see that clause 6 (2) states:

SPEECH.PARA: A Proclamation may also be made . . . in relation to identified property--
Honourable senators should notice that expression--
. . . to which one of more of the following paragraphs applies or apply:

The following paragraphs, including paragraph (d), apply only in relation to identified property which satisfies one or other of those descriptions. So one goes back to the description of 'identified property'. The definition of that is shown in clause 3 (2), which states:
property forming part of the cultural heritage or natural heritage-

That is, for one or other of the two reasons then set out. If one goes back further to definitional clause 3 (1) one sees that 'cultural heritage' and ' natural heritage' are defined by reference to the language of the Convention for the Protection of the World Heritage Cultural and National Heritage. So in each instance there is a chain to the concept of cultural heritage or natural heritage-in other words, property which does satisfy this description of universal value.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans): referred to 'identified property'. Is it property that is identified when this Bill receives royal assent or property that can be identified at a future time?
—Senator Evans may answer that question if he wishes. It is more properly a matter to be raised under the relevant clause.

—Perhaps I can answer the question now to save time being wasted in asking the question again. 'Identified property' is the threshold consideration which applies before anything is proclaimed. The Bill comes into operation only at the stage of proclamation of some 'identified property' or part of 'identified property' as being within the proper subject matter of the Bill. Then, in turn, there have to be further stages of prohibition and so on before anything happens under the Bill. The threshold condition is that of being identified property. It is the proclamation that triggers the application of the Bill.
— How does the property become identified? By whom and at what stage is it identified?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to take Senator Walters on too tedious a course through a process of statutory reading. However, clause 3 (2) states:

SPEECH.PARA: A reference in this Act to identified property shall be read as a reference to-
(a) property forming part of the cultural heritage or natural heritage-

That is identified in one of the following two ways: Firstly, either the Commonwealth has submitted it for inclusion in the World Heritage List or, secondly, it has been identified by virtue of being declared by the regulations to form part of the cultural heritage. So there is a change of machinery that is set out on the face of the Bill for all to read.
Clauses agreed to.
Clause 3 (Interpretation).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, clause 3, paragraph (2) (a), line 15, after ''property'' insert '', land or interest in land''.
(2) Page 2, clause 3, sub-paragraph (2) (a) (ii), lines 21 and 22, leave out the sub-paragraph.

The first amendment, which inserts the words 'land or interest in land' after the word 'property' clarifies this clause a little further. We believe that the word 'property' is used imprecisely here and we submit that there could be occasions when people do not own land but have an interest in it. We fear that the clause, as it stands, could have the effect of applying to only certain property that is owned or alternatively that it may not apply as we would wish to land or interest in land. I do understand that the term is used in the Convention and that it was the Government's intention to cover that point. I do not believe it was the Government's intention not to have covered that point. I seek a statement to that effect from the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) . However, it is our opinion that the Bill does not adequately cover such interests, in which case the owner of an interest in a property or interest in land would not be entitled to compensation pursuant to the Bill.

The second amendment relates to the deletion of clause 3 (2) (a) (ii). It raises some of the fundamental issues of this legislation. We are told that the Bill is essentially to protect South West Tasmania and the basic thrust of the protection of South West Tasmania is because the area has been certified by the World Heritage Committee. Therefore, we query why it is necessary to include matters declared by the regulations which form part of the cultural heritage or natural heritage. I think this matter was partially raised earlier in the Committee stage of the Bill. If the Commonwealth has a view that this measure is necessary, we ask: Why does not the Commonwealth bring in legislation to that effect? Part of the difficulty of this debate is that we seem to seesaw from one side to the other. One minute we are talking about South West Tasmania, as the Attorney-General indicated in his reply in the second reading stage, and the next minute we have to talk about something much more general because the risk is that if we do not the Government will not be able to achieve what it wants in relation to South West Tasmania. In casting that very wide net, a number of problems and real objections arise.

The difficulties that many people have with this Bill-certainly we believe they will arise under the Bill-arise from the fact, as I have just stated, that the Bill is for South West Tasmania but it has had to be dressed up in general terms which give it a much wider application and with special procedures which are necessary because it is South West Tasmania. The Attorney-General shakes his head. I do not want to go into the matter of compensation in any detail at this stage because it will come up later in the debate on the Bill. But one of the reasons we are given that special provisions are necessary is that we have to deal with something that is a bit different from the things that the Government is used to dealing with under normal compensation provisions. That is, we have to deal with this South West Tasmania situation which is not necessarily as easily identified as a piece of land that has to be resumed because an airport or something like that will be built on it. I seek, most earnestly, the Attorney -General's serious attention to the first amendment because it is meant to be a helpful amendment. I do not believe that in replying to this matter in the House of Representatives, Mr Cohen, the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, who is the Minister responsible for this Bill, dealt with the situation that had been raised.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON SECURITY AND INTELLIGENCE AGENCIES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a ministerial statement concerning the Royal Commission on Security and Intelligence Agencies and to move that the Senate take note of that statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

A Royal Commission has now been appointed to conduct a major review of Australian security and intelligence agencies, with a term of reference relating to all the circumstances surrounding the expulsion of Mr Ivanov-including the actions of the Government-and the involvement of Mr David Combe in those circumstances.
The Terms of Reference have already been circulated to Honourable Senators. I seek leave to have them incorporated in Hansard.
The Royal Commissioner is Mr Justice Hope, Judge of Appeal of the Supreme Court of New South Wales. Counsel assisting the Royal Commissioner will be Mr D. M. Ryan, Q.C., of the Melbourne Bar.

I wish to express my gratification at the availability of Mr Justice Hope, and His Honour's acceptance of the Commission. As Honourable Senators will be well aware, Mr Justice Hope has already inquired into and reported on the intelligence and security services of the Australian Government in a series of major reports in 1976 and 1977.

The appointment of the Royal Commission initiates the implementation of my Government's policy for regular judicial audit of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization and close scrutiny of the role and activities of the intelligence community generally. On the occasion of the opening of Parliament the Governor-General conveyed my Government's commitment to amending the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act of 1979 to define more precisely the Organization's jurisdiction and to ensure its private and public accountability.

As I have already indicated to the Parliament, this is not something that is being imposed on the agencies concerned. I have had discussions with their heads , making it clear to them that it was appropriate that there should be a judicial review. That point has been accepted by them, and indeed it has been welcomed by them.

As foreshadowed in Parliament last week, the first matter on which the Royal Commissioner is being asked to report concerns the circumstances surrounding the expulsion of Mr Ivanov, and the involvement of Mr David Combe in those circumstances. The Terms of Reference have been drafted to enable the inquiry to extend to the actions of all relevant persons and organizations, including the Government, in respect of these matters. The Royal Commissioner has been asked to make his report on these matters as soon as possible.

Honourable Senators will see, when they read the Terms of Reference of the Royal Commission, that this inquiry goes far beyond the particular matter of the expulsion of Mr Ivanov, and that it will ensure that the commitment of this Government to a more effective intelligence system is advanced.

Also, the Royal Commission is specifically empowered, by virtue of paragraph (e ) of the Terms of Reference, to make recommendations as to possible changes to the processes and procedures available to Government for dealing with the kind of situation that developed in relation to Mr David Combe.
The Royal Commission will have the full co-operation of the Government. I am sure it will also have the full support of all honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement which has just been incorporated in Hansard is in the same terms as the statement which was made earlier this afternoon by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and relates to a matter which has received a great deal of attention in the Senate over the last week, namely, the Combe affair and the establishment of a royal commission to examine what has colloquially been termed the Combe affair. The intention of the Opposition in the Senate is the same as the intention of the Opposition in the House of Representatives which is to move an amendment to the motion that the Senate take note of the paper, the object of which is to ensure that the terms of reference of the royal commission area are as wide as the Government says that they are. In debate in the other place the Government indicated that it believes that the terms of reference, which have been laid down by the Government, are wide enough to encompass all of the matters of concern which have been raised in Question Time and in debate in this place. It is the concern of the Opposition in the Senate merely to ensure that that is so and to ensure that the royal commission is not prevented from investigating matters which are relevant to the concerns which have been expressed here and elsewhere and which would result in our having an incomplete resolution of these very important matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the first point that needs to be made is that the inquiry is one which, in part at least, is in line with announced Opposition policy and announced Government policy in this field. I would like to remind the Senate that before the last election the then Government issued, as part of its supplementary policy proposals, a statement which was confirmatory of previous statements of the then Government-that is the Fraser Government-that the Government would set up a review of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation towards the end of this year by a senior judge. The object of the inquiry will be to ensure that the Organisation works efficiently and within its charter. To an extent the inquiry which is now announced reflects the intention of the present Government to carry out a similar judicial audit of the security organisations. As the Prime Minister indicated, that is a matter which is welcomed by the security organisations, and it is a matter which is welcomed by the Opposition which itself proposed a similar course of conduct through the words of the now shadow Attorney-General, Senator Durack. The concern that we have is that the inquiry may not be as broad as has been claimed. We are entitled to be a little concerned at the way in which the Government has approached this matter when we look at the quite extraordinary way that the Government arrived at the point at which it was prepared to have an inquiry which touched upon the Ivanov-Combe matter at all.

What is quite clear now is that we have had a chance to examine the earlier answers by Senator Button which were given in the Senate on 12 May is that the judicial inquiry which he told us we were to have and which had initially been set in train a week before the question was raised in the Senate was in fact the judicial audit to which I have referred, and it was a very late decision taken in fact on the day of the announcement to extend the royal commission to pick up the matters which had become matters of public controversy. It is that late change which explains Senator Button's inability, to quote his words, to answer the question put to him as to why what he described as bizarre on the Wednesday became Government policy and the Government's intention on the Thursday.

That fact is quite clear from the Press conference which the Prime Minister held outside Parliament and which was reported extensively in the Sydney Morning Herald of last Friday, but the decision was made on Thursday morning. Our concern is, as I said, not that what is in the terms of reference is something that we would object to but rather that it is potentially incomplete. I specifically refer the Senate to paragraph (c) on page 4 of the terms of reference which States:

Further, to the inquiry in relation to paragraphs (a) and (b) above, all the cirumstances, including the actions of the Government, surrounding the expulsion from Australia of Mr Valeriy Nikolayevich Ivanov, First Secretary, Embassy of the Union of Soviety Socialist Republics, and the involvement of Mr Harvey David Mathew Combe in those circumstances.
On behalf of the Opposition I move:
Leave out all words after 'That', insert:
'the Senate is of the opinion that the terms of reference should be amended by omitting paragraph (c) and substituting the following paragraph:
'(c) further to the inquiry in relation to paragraphs (a) and (b) above:

(i) all the circumstances, including t actions of the Government, surrounding the expulsion from Australia of Mr Valeriy Nikolayevich Ivanov, First Secretary, Embassy of the Union of Soviety Socialist Republics, and the involvement of Mr Harvey David Mathew Combe in those circumstances; and

(ii) whether or not the Prime Minister, the Special Minister of State or any other Minister or any senior Government adviser disclosed confidential information in any way relating to the decision to expel from Australia Mr Valeriy Nikolayevich Ivanov; and' '.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you leave out the Leader of the Opposition? He was consulted too.

—If there were any validity in the argument being put forward by the Government that the existing terms of reference encompass all matters which have been brought into controversy or dispute, it would be true that an inquiry extended in the terms recommended by the Opposition would be more likely to encompass those matters, including the matters raised by the honourable senator by way of interjection. There is certainly no concern on the part of the Opposition to any such inquiry. The positon of the Opposition has been made quite clear in a personal explanation by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), and the fact is that the Opposition is not the source of these matters . It is quite clear, in part at least, on the admission of a Minister from this Government, that there has been a disclosure out of the proper course of important security information by Mr Young.

SPEECH.PARA: The concern of the Opposition is a narrow concern with respect to what is put forward here, and that is whether the words 'all the circumstances' are sufficiently wide to ensure that we get access to or that there is an inquiry not only into the actions immediately surrounding the expulsion but also those various actions which followed the expulsion and which gave rise to public disquiet and concern. The Government has raised, by way of interjection, suggestions about the Opposition. The important question which I think is exercising the minds of many Australians, and certainly the minds of those in the Opposition, is this: Who has been responsible for the leaks? It is abundantly clear that there has been government involvement in the release of security information. Even the best public case for Mr Young indicates that he has given out some security information. Indeed, the Government's own case is that Mr Young has been rebuked by the Prime Minister.

I do not know what a rebuke by the Prime Minister means in any substantial terms. Rebukes have been handed out very frequently by the Prime Minister. They appear to cover a range of misfeasances on the part of Ministers-everything from criticising koala bears to authorising the use of Royal Australian Air Force planes to gather evidence for a case against the State of Tasmania. It does not seem to matter what degree of impropriety is involved; a rebuke from the Prime Minister is apparently the only solution and the only remedy that is required. The Opposition would assert that a mere rebuke is not very substantial and seems to cover a multitude of sins. But in terms of where these leaks come from there is a plethora of material. I do not wish to delay the Senate long but I must touch on some of it to indicate why the Opposition regards it as essential that these matters should be inquired into. In an article by Brian Toohey in the National Times of last Friday Mr Combe was quoted as saying that the Honourable Mick Young had referred to an Australian Labor Party person being involved. That is a matter which gave rise to a great deal of other Press cover. The article stated:

At the Press Club, Combe says, Cameron told him that he had been talking that afternoon to the Special Minister of State, Mick Young, who had suggested that Ivanov had been expelled because he was getting too close to a Labor Party person with influence on the Government. Combe assumed that he was the person referred to.

In the Sunday interview on television, Mr Combe stepped back from that. He indicated that he was being fairer to Mick Young than Mick Young and his ministerial colleagues were being to him. In part of the interview which was not reported until the Sydney Morning Herald article of 16 May Mr Combe made it clear that when he left the Press Club on the same day as his conversation with Mr Cameron he was aware of the involvement of a Labor Party figure. I refer to the Sydney Morning Herald article which says a number of points made in the interview were not included in what was televised but were subsequently released to the Press Gallery. Let me throw in Mr Kelly's conclusions from the additional points which were submitted. He said:

Their significance is that Mr Combe makes it clear that when he left the Press Club on April 22 just a few hours after the Ivanov announcement, he knew it was connected with a KGB man's Labor Party connections.

There are doubts; the Opposition does not claim to know all the facts in this matter, and of course it cannot. But the fact is that on the assertions of Mr Combe over the weekend there have to be significant doubts about what was the source of information which made him so sure that some significant Labor Party figure was involved on that day by the time he left the Press Club. It is quite clear, as I said earlier, that Mr Young stands convicted out of his own mouth. In the PM interview which he did on 13 May he made it quite clear that before there was any public announcement after there had been government consideration of this matter he said to Mr Cameron:
. . . I just said you will understand, you know we are kicking a Russian out this afternoon and we left the office and went to lunch and there was no more said about it.

Of course there is a total lack of knowledge on the part of the public or on the part of the Opposition as to what subsequently transpired and what was a very lengthy lunch for a Minister who has described himself as being so very busy. It would appear from the speech delivered on behalf of the Government by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) that it is the belief of the Government that all these matters are within the jurisdiction or the scope of the Royal Commission, and all that the Opposition is seeking to do in moving this amendment is to put that beyond doubt. If it is not a matter of doubt, why should this amendment not be accepted? In the argument which took place in the other place, the Government again raised the canard that the Opposition was the source of leaks regarding the involvement of Mr Combe. Mr Peacock responded to that in a personal explanation on 12 May in which he made it quite clear that he had not breached the confidential briefing he was given and, indeed, he confirmed that on 21 April, following the briefing, he advised the Prime Minister that he would not even brief his senior colleagues with respect to allegations about Mr Combe. I will not repeat the points which were made at length by Mr Peacock but I refer honourable senators who are interested in them to the House of Representatives Hansard at page 492 of 12 May where that matter is dealt with in detail by the Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you accept his word, why not Mick Young's?

—The fact of the matter is that if, as the Attorney-General interjects, we are not simply to accept his word and let the matter rest, we might look at the views of some other, perhaps more impartial, observers of this scene to see what they regard as the possible source of this matter. The fact is that it was a matter of public notoriety that a senior Australian Labor Party figure was involved and the name of Mr Combe was being freely booted about before he was mentioned in a question raised by the Opposition. It should be noted that, when the name of Mr Combe was raised by the Opposition, it was in relation to the fact that he was no longer acceptable as a lobbyist. Again, that was a matter of public notoriety in the sense that others were acting on the basis of their knowledge that he was not acceptable.

SPEECH.PARA: Understandably, the public is confused when it is faced with Opposition and Government trading allegation against allegation. I suggest that it is instructive in this case to look at what is on the record, at the views of senior Canberra observers and at the sequence of public references to the involvement of a senior Labor Party figure in the Ivanov affair. There has been reference in the Senate to the fact that, as early as 6 May, the National Times made the following comment:

The Labor Government's recent expulsion of a KGB official is causing deep consternation among the very limited number of people in the ALP who have information about an alleged Australian collaborator . . .
It goes on to say:
The accusations were that the collaborator of the KGB official was, in effect, trying improperly to influence the new Government on behalf of the Soviet Union.
That first report was followed by a column written by Mr Laurie Oakes in the Sunday Telegraph of 8 May. This was followed by a new story written by Mr Paul Kelly on the following Monday, 9 May.
I wish to quote from what some senior Press Gallery journalists have written in retrospect. Paul Kelly in the Sydney Morning Herald of 13 May said:
There was no way the lid could be kept on the story. This was because the Government leaked it out. Mr Hawke has nobody to blame but his own Government.
Michelle Grattan, in the Age of 14 May, concluded:
But Mr Combe's name was widely about as the Labor man in the Ivanov affair.
Peter Bowers, in the Sydney Morning Herald of 14 May said;

The Government tried to blame the Opposition for dragging Combe's name into public. The Deputy Leader of the National Party, Ian Sinclair, certainly was the first to name Combe in Parliament, but already the Ivanov-Combe connection was an open secret in Canberra.

They are all observers who are not relying on the unfounded and unsupported assertions of the Leader of the Opposition or his supporters; they are people who have examined the information which was available in Canberra and who have drawn conclusions from it. There are serious issues quite apart from the issue of confidentiality. Who could fail to be perturbed about the way this whole issue was handled by the Government and by the fact that it is now clear that what were described as the unprecedented privileges which were given to Combe in fact amounted to his being given selected extracts of the evidence against him in the course of settling a statement. It is quite clear from what Mr Combe said last weekend that he does not accept the bland assurances that the Government has been trotting forth in this matter. I do not believe that any lawyer could be satisfied with the statement produced, prepared and acquiesced to on the basis of a selective quotation of facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not call you 'crocodile tears' Chaney for nothing, do they?

—We have further interjections from an Attorney-General who has placed himself at the forefront of the civil liberties push in Australia. I do not believe that a single supporter or admirer of his would be even vaguely satisfied with his record in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The ultimate disquiet of the Opposition can be reflected in the differences between what the Prime Minister said as reported at page 506 of Hansard on 12 May and what Senator Evans said here earlier today during Question Time. On 12 May, the Prime Minister said:

. . . this Government moved to do everything immediately within its power to see that Mr Combe had every opportunity to look at the facts as we, the Government, knew those facts. On the basis of those facts, we believed in terms of the interest of this country that we had to act. Mr Combe understood and accepted our decision.

It is not possible to marry the words of the Prime Minister, that the Government had done everything within its power to see that Mr Combe had every opportunity to look at the facts as the Government knew those facts, with what was admitted by the Attorney-General here today and what was inferentially known from the statements of the Government up to that time, namely, that only selected quotations had been read to Mr Combe in the course of this interview.

The fact is that there is no room for doubt in these matters. They are required to be settled once and for all to the satisfaction of the Australian people by their being subject to a proper inquiry. It is the wish of the Opposition simply to ensure that the inquiry is wide enough to encompass these matters. The two versions of what was done with respect to Mr Combe I think alone ought to satisfy the Senate that there is a problem which demands attention. There is a developing chasm between what Senator Evans and the Prime Minister now say was Mr Combe's attitude and the way he described it over the weekend. The Opposition believes that the Government is taking huge backward steps in an effort to justify the earlier sweeping assurances from both the Attorney-General and the Prime Minister. We want to see the terms of reference for the royal commission tightened up so that there is no chance of those involved in the post-expulsion actions escaping the scrutiny of the commissioner. Accordingly, I have moved the amendment, circulated in my name, which had previously been moved by the Leader of the Opposition in the other place and I urge the Senate to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Australian Democrats welcome the appointment of the royal commission on Australia's five security and intelligence services particularly since it is some nine years since the last royal commission was appointed to inquire into those services and some six and a half years since it reported. Security services and organisations are in receipt of some $37m annually in order to preserve law, order and public safety in this country. Therefore, I believe it is not unreasonable that some accountability both to the Government and to the general public pertains. I cannot therefore quite understand the apologetic tone of the comments in paragraph 2 on page 2 of the ministerial statement, which are rather redolent of a forelock tugging exercise. At the end of paragraph 1, the Government announces the setting up of the commission as being in keeping with a statement made in the Governor-General 's Speech at the opening of Parliament. Paragraph 2 of the statement goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: As I have already indicated to the Parliament, this is not something that is being imposed on the agencies concerned. I have had discussions with their heads , making it clear to them that it was appropriate that there should be a judicial review. That point has been accepted by them, and indeed it has been welcomed by them.

I cannot quite understand why the Government has to apologise for calling these agencies to order or for reasonably requesting that that take place. Indeed, had they objected, I would have expected the Government to impose those very requirements.

A non-accountable security service, or any other authority, invites at best the squandering of public money of the sort that was revealed recently concerning the Peanut Marketing Board of Queensland and at worst the sort of draconian and irrational invasion of individual liberties and privacy normally only expected of totalitarian regimes. I hasten to point out that in that instance I am not necessarily referring to Queensland. The keeping of secret files on who meets whom, where, how often and for how long has no place in a democracy. Witch hunts and sneaky leaks to selective journalists are, or at least ought to be anathema in a free society. It is certainly not a legitimate role of our security agencies that they undertake these sorts of activities.

The Australian Democrats support the existence of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and its brother or sister agencies that are mentioned in the ministerial statement, although we regret, of course, that we do not have the perfect society that would allow us to live without them. It is, unfortunately, necessary for us to have organisations such as these to ensure the safety and security of the country and of its citizens. We believe, however, that given the constraints of preserving national security, those organistions charged with the brief of maintaining law, order and security in this country must operate efficiently, effectively and properly and must be accountable.

The terms of reference of this commission will ensure that a full and complete inquiry into the operations of Australia's security agencies is undertaken. We believe that the Opposition's amendments add nothing to those terms of reference . I believe that the first amendment is superfluous since it repeats word for word, and indeed, comma for comma, paragraph (c) in the Government's own terms of reference.

The second is unnecessary since it is, we believe, essentially covered in paragraph (d) which refers to 'any other related matters to which the attention of the Commission is directed by the Prime Minister in the course of the inquiry '.

I do not believe that either the Government or the official Opposition has much to be proud of as far as the Combe saga is concerned. They have willingly, whether deliberately or not, conspired to ruin an individual's reputation and livelihood. I would therefore probably be more inclined to accept the Opposition 's amendment if it included in its second paragraph the words 'the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the National Party'. I say, therefore, that the only good that appears to have come from the whole sorry affairs is that it appears to have hastened the appointment of this royal commission.

We support this inquiry. We hope that it will be able to report as fully and as expeditiously as possible and, if necessary, in the case of Mr Combe as far as justice and fair play are concerned, bring down an interim report at least on that section. The Hope committee of 1974 took some two years to bring out its report.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is in the terms of reference.

—That is fine, as long as it is clearly there. The man has been damaged enough as it is without his having to wait for two years or more before the report is brought down. We will oppose the Opposition's amendments to the terms of reference, as I have said, on the grounds that they are both unnecessary and superfluous.
