PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Peter Rae) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to provide for automatic and simultaneous dissolution of both Houses of the Parliament in the event of disagreement between the Houses in relation to the passing of proposed laws appropriating revenue or moneys for ordinary annual services of the Government, and for related purposes.
Bill presented by Senator Peter Rae, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Mr President, the long title of this proposed law is 'A Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to provide for automatic and simultaneous dissolution of both Houses of the Parliament in the event of disagreement between the Houses in relation to the passing of proposed laws appropriating revenue or moneys for ordinary annual services of the Government, and for related purposes'.

The question of the Senate and Supply has been under consideration by the Australian Constitutional Convention and its Standing Committee 'D' for a number of years. It arises from concern over the possibillity that the Senate has, at present, the capacity to force the House of Representatives to an early election without necessarily being required also to face election. Many Australians, including me, regard this as a major deficiency. It was at Perth in 1978 that the Convention, after considering competing proposals and a report from Standing Committee 'D', took the first positive step toward reaching a resolution of the matter, when it was decided to recommend that the Constitution be amended to provide for automatic dissolution of the two Houses if the Senate rejected or failed to pass within a certain time an appropriation for the ordinary annual services of the Government. This decision and related matters were referred again to Standing Committee 'D' for detailed drafting consideration-taking into account the matters raised by delegates during the debate.

Standing Committee 'D' comprised 17 members and, in addition, Senator Gareth Evans and myself were members during consideration of the resolution on the Senate and Supply. The Standing Committee was representative of all States, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory.

Standing Committee 'D' made a number of reports, the most recent being the fourth report (dated 27 August 1982), the recommendations of which were, with an amendment I shall come to, adopted at Adelaide last month. Honourable Senators will find the reports, particularly the fourth report which is in two volumes, of great value in their consideration of the proposal now before the Senate.

Let me stress immediately that the Bill faithfully expresses the decisions made by the Australian Constitutional Convention held at Adelaide in April of this year. The governing principle of the Bill is that the Constitution should be altered to provide that, if the Senate within 30 days fails to pass a Bill appropriating revenue or moneys for ordinary annual services of the Government of a particular year only and dealing only with such appropriation, the Governor -General shall forthwith dissolve the Senate and the House of Representatives simultaneously. I submit that such a provision is consistent with the high principle of Westminster style government that a Government which has been denied Supply by the Parliament cannot govern and should advise a general election or resign. It is also consistent with the, I think, general opinion that, if the Senate blocks Supply to force an election of the House of Representatives, the Senate, the whole Senate, should also face the judgment of the people.

But, Mr President, what are ordinary annual services of the Government? Clearly , the meaning of the expression is open to differences of opinion. However, Standing Committee ''D'' did not spell out what were, or what were not, appropriations for ordinary annual services of the Government. If that position were to remain, there is the danger that any or all appropriations might be classified as appropriations for ordinary annual services, thus not only undermining the Senate's amendment power but also creating possible unreal double dissolution situations where a dispute between the Houses over an appropriation-perhaps minor and unconnected to the mainstream of Supply for ordinary annual services-and which is not resolved within 30 days or less, may lead to a mandatory double dissolution. Such a consequence would be totally unacceptable.
Fully to make my point, Mr President, which I believe is vital to a proper operation of the proposed Constitutional changes, I find it necessary to expound the matter of ordinary annual services.
The expression ''ordinary annual services of the Government'' is employed:

(a) in section 53 of the Constitution to classify the expenditure in respect of which the Senate's powers of amendment are restricted to requesting the House of Representatives to make amendments; and
(b) in section 54 to protect the Senate against the tacking of extraneous matters to an Appropriation Bill for the ordinary annual services of the Government, which the Senate may not amend.

The very first budget bills were in 1901, returned to the House of Represenatives by the Senate insisting that the form of presentation be changed to a more appropriate form. Over the years the Senate has been vigilant in ensuring a proper classification of ordinary annual services, thus protecting its amendment power which, I submit, is of even more importance than the veto power. Matters were arranged reasonably well for some 50 years. Then in 1952 the practice of processing the Appropriation (Works and Services) Bill as a Bill not for the ordinary annual services of the Government was challenged, but the Senate confirmed the ruling of the then President that it was a Bill which a Senate may amend. Then in 1964 the Government of the day made a statement announcing that the contents of the Appropriation Bill and the Appropriation ( Works and Services) Bill would be amalgamated except for some small special expenditure. This announcement led to the appointment by the Government Senators of the day of a Committee on Appropriation Bills and the ordinary annual services of the Government. The recommendations of the Committee, consisting of Senators Cormack (Chairman) and Senators McKellar, Wedgwood and Wright, were largely adopted by the Government and became known as the Compact of 1965.

This was the product of careful consideration and negotiation between the two houses. In brief, the Compact excluded from the ordinary annual services of the Government appropriations for the construction of public works and buildings, acquisition of sites and buildings, certain plant and equipment, section 96 grants to the States, and new policies not authorised by special legislation. Under the Compact, all such appropriations were to be subject to Senate amendment.

Later, in 1976, the Chairman of the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee (Senator Missen) brought up a report stating that, on behalf of the Committee, he had written to the then Treasurer seeking his views as to whether or not the procedure contained in the Compact of 1965 in respect of ordinary annual expenditure would be followed in future appropriation legislation. The Treasurer replied in the affirmative. Arising from the report the Senate resolved on 17 February 1977, on the motion of Senator Missen, to reaffirm the Compact of 1965.

With that history in mind, and supported by an opinion of Mr Ewart Smith ( formerly Deputy Secretary, Attorney-General's Department) who in a paper to Standing Committee 'D' observed that the Compact of 1965 may be seen as approaching the status of a convention, I proposed at the Australian Constitutional Convention, to the motion that the report of the Standing Committee 'D' be adopted, an amendment to insert a new section 53A in the constitution to give statutory recognition to the Compact of 1965, with drafting modifications, and the addition of appropriations for the services of Parliament which under current practice are the subject of a separate Appropriation Bill not deemed to be for the ordinary annual service of the Government. The amendment was agreed to by the Australian Constitutional Convention and forms clause 3 of the Bill now before the Senate.

There are difficulties in defining what are ordinary annual services. Honourable Senators will note that clause 3 approaches the question of classifying appropriations from the point of defining what is not 'ordinary annual services'. This is seen as a more workable approach than attempting to define what is comprised in 'ordinary annual services'.
I cannot, I believe, overemphasise the need for new section 53A of the Constitution as contained in clause 3 of the Bill. Let me give the Senate an illustration.

Without the amendment, and with the wide open interpretation by Government of what are ordinary annual services, the proposals put forward by Standing Committee 'D' may have led toi a situation where the Senate, in the exercise of its function as a States House, and in attempting to ensure the rectification of an inequity between the States-say, for instance, by amending or rejecting some grant, or form of financial assistance, to one State to the detriment of another , might find itself forced into a double dissolution on the grounds of blocking Supply. That surely would be a strong dissuader to the Senate to act in its proper role in ensuring equity between the States and the Commonwealth. But the dissuader would exist if grants to the States were to be processed as appropriations for ordinary annual services and not in accordance with the amendment contained in new section 53A. Let us, therefore, entrench in the Constitution this amendment which has at its roots the ensuring of some certainty in the protection of the interests of the States and of the relationship between the houses of this Parliament and the workability of the other proposals for resolving the issue of the Senate and Supply. It will control the content of Appropriation Bills and, furthermore, be of assistance to the Governor-General in determining whether grounds for any double dissolution are proper.

It is true that it is proposed by sub-section (4) of proposed new section 54 of the Constitution that within 30 days after assent an appeal may be made to the High Court challenging matter in an Appropriation Bill on the ground that the matter is other than an appropriation for ordinary annual services of a particular year only, and the High Court may declare the matter of no effect. However, the proposed appeal to the court is after the event-that is, after double dissolution is involved. Nevertheless, the provision could prove useful, although with new section 53A the need for the involvement of the High Court should not arise.

From what I have said, I trust that honourable Senators will be persuaded of the importance of having defined, at least what are not ordinary annual services of the Government. I see it as crucial to the whole scheme of the Bill. The Senate-and of course the Governor-General-must know where they stand and know what proposed expenditure may be the subject of double dissolution.

I turn now to certain other important features of the Bill. Of much importance are amendments to the second paragraph of section 53 (restrictions on Senate's power of amendment of appropriations for ordinary annual services), section 54(1 ) (protection against tacking), and proposed new section 54A (providing for double dissolutions), which make it clear that those several provisions apply only to appropriations for a particular year. As the notes contained in the report of Standing Committee ''D'' explain, the Senate would be free to reject or amend, without exposing itself to dissolution, any Bill that proposed to make appropriations, in whatever form, covering ordinary annual services for a period of more than one year.

Another important and related matter is that contained in proposed new section 54(2), which is designed to prevent long term supply for salaries and allowances of public servants, administrative expenses of departments, and Defence pay and allowances. It is provided that any appropriation for such expenditure shall not have effect unless it is made by a law that relates to services of a particular year only and is passed, or is deemed to have been passed, by the Senate not earlier than six months before the commencement of that year. The effect is to prohibit standing appropriations for those classes of ordinary annual expenditure without which it would be virtually impossible for a Government to carry on and prevents possible abuse by a Government obtaining supply for the whole of its term in its first year.

Mr President, I refer now to the proposed amendment to section 57 of the Constitution, which is the existing mechanism for double dissolution when there is disagreement between the Houses. Section 57 is to remain, but it is proposed by the Bill that the section not apply in relation to a proposed law appropriating revenue or moneys for ordinary annual services of the Government of a particular year only and dealing only with such appropriation. However, it is proposed that the one dissolution may be founded on both new section 54A and section 57, circumstances permitting.

Next I draw attention to the eminently sensible provision in the Bill that the Governor-General in Council may authorise expenditure for a double dissolution election and to maintain ordinary annual services of the Government after dissolution until 21 days after the House of Representatives next meets. If I have a reservation about the Bill, it is the provision that after dissolution the Appropriation Bill which was the subject of the dissolution may be presented for assent after passing the House of Representatives only, the Senate having no say in the matter. I see this proposal as a down-grading of the Senate in the federal system and a rejection of the Federal Compact and the States which demanded as the price of federation a States Assembly having equal financial power with the House of Representatives, except for the financial initiative. It follows that the Senate's continued participation in the legislative process following a double dissolution is necessary to uphold the time-honoured Constitutional and Federal principle that Supply is the joint grant of the two Houses. My preference, therefore, in the event of a deadlock after dissolution over Supply is to apply the joint sitting device, as in section 57 of the Constitution.

If the majority will of a totality of elected members of Parliament be against supply, then it should be a matter of the whole disagreement and decision being sent back to the people. That is in the spirit of the Constitution. However, I face the fact that the Bill before the House represents the collective wisdom of the Australian Constitutional Convention and, accordingly, I give way on this point for the sake of the greater good in the Bill.

There is one final matter to which I should refer. This Bill is all about resolving disagreement between the Houses in relation to the blocking of Supply with respect to ordinary annual services. There is, I recognise, a significant area of Supply which is not for ordinary annual services; but, if the Constitutional changes proposed in this Bill are adopted, I do not believe that there will be a problem in respect of Supply for appropriations which are not for the ordinary annual services. If the Senate is intent on blocking Supply and forcing a double dissolution, the battleground will be on an appropriation Bill for ordinary annual services and there would be no point in blocking a Bill for appropriations other than for ordinary annual services. So far as the latter appropriations are concerned, the Senate's main concern is to have and to retain the power to make any necessary amendment and that objective is achieved by the proposals in the Bill. So, with an understanding of what are and what are not ordinary annual services as proposed in the Bill, any continuing legislative disagreement between the Houses in respect of appropriations not for ordinary annual services may safely be left to the operation of section 57, which is the existing mechanism for resolving disagreement.

Mr President, I conclude as I began by re-stating that this Bill for the resolution of the question of the Senate and Supply faithfully expresses the decisions of the Australian Constitutional Convention. We are much indebted to the Convention and its Standing Committee ''D'' for their long and patient deliberation of the matter and for their considered resolution reached at Adelaide last month. In the spirit of consensus, which is the prevailing mood of the electorate, let us thank the Australian Constitutional Convention, accept the careful and well considered findings and recommendations, and give this Bill a speedy passage.
Mr President, I thank the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Grimes) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Wine Research Institute-Death of Kenneth Dax-Royal Military College, Duntroon

PROCTEXT.PARA: Australian Wine Research Institute-Death of Kenneth Dax-Royal Military College, Duntroon

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being a little after 7 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise in the adjournment debate tonight a matter that was the subject of a question by an honourable senator earlier today to which no definitive answer was given. I refer to the sacking of two scientists employed by the Australian Wine Research Institute. I am taking the step of discussing the matter in the adjournment debate since no question, however lengthy, can canvass all the issues relating to this matter, nor cover all the background. I wish to go back to 13 October 1982. To begin with, I refer to a staff memo headed: 'Staff request for elected representative to be at Council Meetings'. A letter which was sent to the staff from the Chairman of the Council, Mr G. L. G. Anderson, stated in part:

SPEECH.PARA: The members generally can understand and appreciate the motivation leading to this request and are very sympathetic to suggestions for improving communication between members of the staff and the Council.
However, he stated in a subsequent paragraph that the Council took the following view:

. . . the Director of the Institute is the most appropriate person to act as liaison between the Council and staff. He could be responsible for briefing council members on the operations of the Institute and at the same time should be making representations on behalf of the staff professionally as well as in matters pertaining to employee welfare.
I am not sure that those two elements are not mutually exclusive in some cases. The third paragraph stated:

It is the wish of Council to give the incoming Director, Dr Lee, every opportunity to develop, in his own way, correct and harmonious relationships between the staff and the council and we have every confidence that he will direct himself to that end as a matter of priority when he commences duties.

Dr Lee did launch his career as Director of the Australian Wine Research Institute with some enthusiam, but I am not sure that it was in the best interests either of the employees of the Institute itself or even of wine research in this country. On 8 April 1983 Dr Lee issued a directive entitled ' Employment terms and conditions' in which he set out the new system, having pointed out that in the past the Institute had never adopted its own terms and conditions of employment for staff but had used those of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation-a matter which was apparently satisfying as far as the staff was concerned for some quarter of a century. He stated:
In 1981 the Institute became a respondent to 'The Professional Scientists Award and Agreements'.
He informed the staff on 8 April 1983:

The Council of the Institute has agreed that the Institute should develop its own terms and conditions of employment, complementary to, and in addition to, the terms and conditions of the Professional Scientists Award and Agreements.

On 26 April a number of employees of the Australian Wine Research Institute wrote to Dr Lee protesting at this change in terms of employment, saying that they did not see any good reason at this stage for changing those conditions and that they were disappointed that there was no consultation with them prior to receipt of the letter. They said that they seriously considered the matter and at that stage were not prepared to accept the proposed changes, particularly as they did not know specifically what they were. At least two members had found out some days prior to that that the proposed changes included termination of employment at the discretion of the Director and at a moment's notice, something which was hardly conducive to improving staff morale. On 22 April, that is, four days before the staff letter was sent to the Director, two members of the Institute, one of whom had been employed for 11 years and the other for 16 years , received a letter from Dr Lee which, in two short paragraphs, terminated their services on the grounds that those services were 'no longer required by the Institute'. One month's pay was given in lieu of notice.

The research which is done by the Institute and by the two scientists concerned has received not only national respect but also international respect. A flood of protest poured into the Institute not only from Australian scientists and organisations, but also from overseas organisations, and included a telegram-a copy of which I have-from France. This is not some small bicker between a director of an organisation and a couple of superfluous staff. It is a problem which has arisen between a new broom and the dust of which he is apparently trying to sweep the place clean. The Press took up the issue late in April and early in May, and contacted not only the two scientists who had been sacked, but also their superior, Dr Somers. An article in the News stated:
. . . he still did not know why his assistants had been sacked . . . 'Their scientific data had been thrown out as if it was a load of rubbish.'
The work of the Institute at Urrbrae had been set back, and the sacked scientists had been treated with contempt.
The reputation of the institute had been hit fairly severely, 'not only locally , but overseas.'

The Chairman of the Council, when contacted, said that the Council had approved the sackings on the recommendation and advice of the new Director, Dr Lee. No wonder, one presumes, a staff member was not wanted on the Council. Dr Forrest, who retired as Institute Director last July and, therefore, should have some knowledge of the competence of the staff, said that he was astonished at what was happening at the centre and that he regarded the two scientists concerned as competent. I understand that the Department of Primary Industry has a representative on the Institute Council and was presumably, therefore, involved in the vote which was taken approving those dismissals. At no stage has anything I have seen shown whether the Council was unanimous in supporting Dr Lee's recommendations or whether there was some dissent. No details of the debate have been made known. But because the Department is involved, and because Federal Government money is directed to research at the Institute, the Parliament and the people concerned are entitled to know what action the Goverment will take to see to the reinstatement of the two scientists concerned-it is hoped with some compensation for whatever damage has been done to their reputations-and that a full inquiry is instigated into the whole sorry affair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise an issue which I have raised on a number of occasions. This is merely the next sorry episode in the saga. I refer to the tragic death of Kenneth Dax. I refer to a letter that Mrs Dax received from the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) in relation to the still outstanding claims made by Mr and Mrs Dax on their son's death. The present Minister for Defence has gone part of the way towards meeting those outstanding claims. The present Minister for Defence, unlike the previous Minister, at least has shown some compassion and has now undertaken that the costs will be met. The Minister has also released to Mr and Mrs Dax a copy of the review of the board of inquiry report, with appropriate deletions, and has outlined fully in his letter how the parents may go about appealing against the deletions that were made. Kenneth Dax was gassed while on cadet training on HMAS Tobruk. The Minister has seen fit not to resolve the final outstanding point and allow an ex gratia payment to the parents. The Minister's letter shows yet again the hidden hand of the people in bureaucracy who have been in charge of this matter for so long and who are still unwilling to admit liability. The Minister stated that the Commissioner for Compensation had informed the Daxes on 14 May 1982 that there was no liability on the Commonwealth. The Daxes have accepted that position. I do not know why every letter that is sent out wishes to reinforce that point. There has been no contention on the part of the Daxes that the Commonwealth had that legal liability. The discussion was in relation to the moral liability that the Commonwealth ought to assume in this case. The Daxes, because of the death of their son, have been attempting to establish some precendents so that other parents in like situations will have automatic redress, rather than the enormous pain, hurt and distress that have been caused to them. The Minister's letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: The award, instead of compensation, of an ex gratia payment has been carefully considered but that would amount to circumvention of the provisions of existing legislation.

The absurdity of that point is revealed only if one carefully reads it again. The whole idea of an ex gratia payment is that it is not covered by legislation. That is the point that has been constantly made. There is no legislative liability on the Commonwealth at all; that is accepted. It must be accepted, and it will be accepted eventually by this Government that there is a moral liability in this case, although it was not accepted by the previous Government and is not accepted by the present Minister. The parents will not give up, and those who are supporting them in this matter will not give up. This is not a situation in which private individuals can be brushed off. The Commonwealth must eventually accept the moral responsibility for what occurred in this most tragic case. It must not only accept the moral responsibility and undertake to pay the ex gratia payment but go further. It must examine the legislation in this regard so that legislative action can be taken to ensure that no further incidents of this kind arise on Commonwealth property. This situation must not be allowed to continue. I simply urge the Government to consider this case yet again, because it will not go away with the writing of a polite letter. It will remain, and the parents will continue to fight for that moral justice which is their just desert .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise again the matter of bastardisation at the Royal Military College, Duntroon, because I am not yet completely satisfied that it has been resolved on a permanent basis. I have believed for some time, in fact since the announcement was made that five cadets were to be expelled, that cadets should not have been expelled. This is not because I in any way approved of their actions, but because I thought the role of the military staff at Duntroon had not been sufficiently examined, and because I have been getting information from areas of the community I feel I can trust that bastardisation has been very much part of the tradition at Duntroon for a long time and that the military staff have ignored it, if not actually connived at it. Because of this I applaud the decision of the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) last week not to expel those cadets. Indeed, he has stated an intention to look more carefully at the role of the military staff at Duntroon.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me axiomatic that effective discipline should be intrinsic to any military operation. If the bastardisation processes are being connived at or tolerated by the military staff, that is to be greatly deplored. In fact, it would be a disgraceful situation. But if, indeed, the custom cannot be controlled by the military staff, there would seem to be a breach of discipline equally to be deplored. Either way the matter must be pursued and I now seek from the Government some undertaking that it will keep a close eye on the matter , over the next few years if necessary, to see that it stops absolutely, that the military staff at Duntroon make it a matter of discipline to see that it stops, and that they are in a position to see that it stops.

There have been reports, which I think are reliable, that this sort of excessive behaviour has been common at Duntroon for quite some time and has become traditional. Colonel C. W. T. Kyngdon is on record as saying that, when he was at the college between 1929 and 1932, it was thought that the practice started around 1920 when an RMC officer visited West Point in the United States of America and introduced bastardisation at Duntroon on his return. Colonel Kyngdon has recalled some extremely revolting examples from his time. I think the recent things do not seem to have been as extreme as those. I have received reports that junior cadets had cups of coffee poured over them, that they were smeared with buttered toast, that they were taunted with offensive suggestions about female relatives and friends, that they were sent on useless errands during work, sleep and eating times and that they were locked in a cupboard filled by smoke from burning toast. I suggest that these are rather juvenile actions and I cannot for the life of me see how they will contribute to the development of any great military spirit. Only one case that has been reported to me is perhaps worth recording as being of a more serious nature. I have heard of a case in which a loaded gun was pointed at a cadet's head and the trigger was pulled without mentioning to the cadet that the bolt was missing from the rifle. I do not find that very funny.

This behaviour has been justified in letters to various editors of newspapers in the last week or so. That is my second reason for raising it now. It has been said by people who ought to know better that Duntroon is not a girls' school, that its graduates must be tough and that bastardisation develops the instinct for survival and produces qualities of endurance, tolerance and determination that are often lacking in young Australians of today. I suggest that the types of behaviour I have cited lamentably lack the ability to develop those sorts of qualities. I do not think any sort of justification for them exists. As a result , this sort of behaviour should not be justified on any terms whatsoever. The fact is that many fine officers have been produced in other military establishments around Australia without this sort of punishment. I will conclude by quoting briefly from a letter which Mr Francis James wrote to the Age on 29 April and in which he makes the point very well:

It is entirely proper for the commandant to show that loyalty to his staff that some of them have obviously not shown him: some of them were clearly not energetic enough in preventing 'excessive behaviour'. This is not good enough for me and other citizen taxpayers.

A constructive suggestion is this. Duntroon should at once abolish the system of separate cadet messes. Cadets should mess with their officers. If that happens not be the RMC tradition, then it is time a new tradition started.

At Point Cook in my time, nearly 50 years ago, officers and cadets shared the same mess, the same anteroom. We were not told by another mere cadet how officers and gentleman behaved: we learned by example-and what a splendid example it was.

Nothing remotely resembling 'bastardisation' ever occurred. 'Supervision' was minimal by day, nil at night. I am not aware that RAAF officers, as a result, proved professionally inferior to their army counterparts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Haines raised a matter which was first raised by Senator Crowley during Question Time today. Senator Walsh at the time said that he would seek further information from the relevant Minister and is doing so, but as yet has not received sufficient of information sought by Senator Haines. I assure her that that is being pursued and that we will get a reply for her as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly, I have no personal knowledge of the details of the cases referred to by Senator Mason and the matters involved in the investigation of bastardisation at Duntroon. I will refer that to the relevant Minister to see whether we can get a reply.

However, Senator Macklin's problem affects me as the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act and the Office of the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation come under my portfolio. I was made aware of the Dax case recently and asked for a report from the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation. I have received an initial report. Certainly the compensation available under the Act for the unfortunate parents of this lad is not sufficient in my view or in anybody's view. It is interesting that the Queensland workers compensation Act, as do the Victorian, Western Australian and Tasmanian workers compensation Acts, provides for a lump sum to be paid on the death of a minor without dependants.

At present the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act provides that unavoidable costs associated with such a death can be met by the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation and this is done through an ex gratia payment with the approval of the Minister for Finance. But as Senator Macklin said, more than this is needed. The Act needs to be looked at under these circumstances. I assure him that I am in the process of doing that with the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation and the Department. Certainly it is a most unfortunate case. The distress caused to these people was difficult enough without their having the hassle they have had under our inadequate compensation laws. I will let Senator Macklin and other honourable senators know of progress as we look at this case in more detail and work out how we can amend the legislation satisfactorily.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Visits by Nuclear Powered or Armed Ships

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 22 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has an inter-departmental committee on naval dockyard development studied the question of visits and/or base porting of nuclear powered or armed ships in Australian ports; if so when did the committee report.
(2) Did the committee report that 'Sydney Harbour is generally unsuited for either the routine operation or the occassional refitting of nuclear warships'; if so, what were the reasons.
(3) Did the committee make any recommendations with respect to other Australian ports; if so, what were the recommendations and the reasons for them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An interdepartmental committee in 1970 was charged to investigate and make recommendations concerning the development of naval dockyards and associated facilities for the maintenance, repair, refit, et cetera of warships in Australia during the 1970s. As part of its report it considered the issues that would be raised if, at some time in the future, it was decided either to acquire nuclear powered warships for the Royal Australian Navy or to provide home port and dockyard repair and maintenance facilities for foreign nuclear powered warships. Dockyard repair and maintenance work on nuclear powered warships involve considerations significantly different from those that apply to port visits by those vessels. Any quotations drawn from the report should be understood within the general context of maintenance, repair and refit of a dockyard kind.
(2) The report stated that Sydney Harbour is generally unsuited for repair maintenance or dockyard maintenance of nuclear warships for the following reasons:
the naval berths and dockyards are closely surrounded by dense urban population ;
there is no area suitable to provide a remote berth or anchorage for use in an emergency or for 'cooling off' the reactor before entry to the port area;
the congested port increases risk of collision;
the port is of such commercial importance that it would have serious consequences to the economy if incapacitated by a nuclear accident.
(3) The committee considered sites at Williamstown, Cockburn Sound, Garden Island (Western Australia) and Jervis Bay:
(a) Williamstown was deemed unsuitable as an operating or refitting base for nuclear ships due to objections similar to those raised in relation to the use of Sydney Harbour;
(b) the committee thought that Cockburn Sound could probably satisfy the safety requirements as a support facility for nuclear warships;
(c) it was recommended that Garden Island (Western Australia) should be investigated to determine its suitability as an operating base for nuclear ships ;

(d) Jervis Bay was considered to have some potential for development as an operating and refitting base but I would note that population growth and development in the area over the past 12 years would require reconsideration of this assessment were circumstances in the future to suggest a need.
I would however point out that present government policy would not permit:
(a) acquisition of nuclear vessels
(b) establishment of service or maintenance facilities for nuclear ships
(c) basing or homeporting of nuclear ships.
